CHAPTER 77:  PARKING SCHEDULES



Schedule



   I.   Prohibited parking



   II.   Residential parking areas



SCHEDULE I.  PROHIBITED PARKING.



   (A)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle in any of
the following areas: On the east side or west side of Central Avenue between
163rd Street on the south and Margie Lane on the north.



   (B)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle on 163rd
Street from Long Avenue to Central Avenue on either side of the street from
9:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. of the following day.



   (C)   Parking shall not be permitted along 151st Street from Oak
Park Avenue to Chestnut Road within the city limits. Council shall prohibit
future parking at locations on or immediately adjacent to 151st Street as may
be determined and directed by the County of Cook to be necessary to ensure
the free flow of traffic and safety to the motoring public.



   (D)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on El
Vista Avenue from 151st Street to LaPalm Drive, or on Vine Street from Sunset
Avenue to Mission Avenue. Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on
School Days 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m."



   (E)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle at 151st
Street on El Vista Avenue. Limits: "No Parking Here to Corner."



   (F)   No person shall park any vehicle between the signs posted on
Mission Avenue at 151st Street.



   (G)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle from
Waverly Avenue to Cicero Avenue on the south side of 156th Street. Limits:
"No Parking Anytime."



   (H)   Parking shall not be permitted along Route 50 (Cicero Avenue)
from 149th Street to Route 6 within the city limits. Council shall prohibit
future parking at locations on or immediately adjacent to Route 50 (Cicero
Avenue) as may be determined and directed by the state and the city to be
necessary to ensure the free flow of traffic and safety to the motoring
public.



   (I)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on the
north side of 151st Street between Central Avenue and Long Avenue. Limits:
"No Parking Anytime."



   (J)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on Fawn
Court. Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days - 8:00 a.m.
to 4:00 p.m."



   (K)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the
areas and in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: North side of
Waverly Avenue between Cicero Avenue and 156th Street. Limits: "6:00 a.m. to
6:00 p.m."



   (L)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not displaying a
residential parking permit, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose
operators are doing business with the residents living at these addresses, at
the following location: Chaucer Drive from Victoria Drive to Rob Roy Drive.
Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days 8:00 a.m. to 3:00
p.m."



   (M)   The area commonly described as the west side of Long Avenue
from 151st Street to Woodland Drive is designated as a "No Parking Area."



   (N)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the
area and in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: Ann Marie and
Natalie Drives south of 155th Street. Limits: Posted signs on the side of the
streets where fire hydrants exist.



   (O)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the
area and in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: From 15420/21
and Hickory Lane to Victoria Drive. Limits: "No Parking Here to Corner
-School Days Only."



   (P)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not registered to a
resident of that street, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose
operators are doing business with the residents living at these addresses, at
the following location: Sunset Park and El Vista Avenues from LaPalm Drive
South. Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days 8:00 a.m.
to 2:00 p.m."



   (Q)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle from 12:00
p.m. to 4:00 p.m. during school days on Long Avenue from Diamond Drive to
155th Street.



   (R)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not registered to a
resident of that street, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose
operators are doing business with the residents living at these addresses, at
the following location: 5340 and 5350 West 146th Street.



   (S)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the
areas and in violation of the limits as indicated below: No parking here to
corner on both the East and West sides of Laramie Avenue from 16700 to
Aldersyde.



   (T)   Parking shall not be permitted along the following streets:



      (1)   Oak from 159th Street to 160th Street;



      (2)   160th Street from Oak Street to Cicero Avenue;



      (3)   160th Street from Oak Avenue to Grove Avenue (north
side); and



      (4)   Forest Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street (east
side).



   (U)   Pursuant to § 73.10. it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle
in the following location: north side of Victoria Drive (between 5630
Victoria Drive and Chaucer Drive).



   (V)   Pursuant to § 73.10. it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle
between the east exit and west entrance at 5151 W. 149th Street commonly
known as Ridge School. This will be indicated by "No Parking" signs erected,
installed and maintained by the City of Oak Forest Director of Public Works.



(2000 Code, § 10.28.010)  (Ord. 2675, §§ 1, 2, passed - -2002; Ord. 2662,
§§ 1, 2, passed - -2002; Ord. 2757, §§ 1, 2, passed - -2003; Ord. 2756,
§§ 1, 2, passed - -2003; Ord. 2731, § 2, passed - -2003; Ord. 2838, § 1,
passed - -2004; Ord. 2809, §§ 1, 2, passed - -2004; Ord. 2895, §§ 1, 2,
passed - -2005; Ord. 2890, §§ 1, 2, passed - -2005; Ord. 2006-11-0070O,
passed 11-28-2006; Ord. 2007-11–0134O, passed 11-13-2007; Ord.
2007-11-0138O, passed 11-27-2007; Am. Ord. 2010-03-0284O, passed 3-23-2010;
Am. Ord. 2018-07-0695, passed 7-24-2018)



SCHEDULE II: RESIDENTIAL PARKING AREAS.



   (A)   Establishment. The city creates certain residential parking
areas. These areas shall include the following:



      (1)   Mission Avenue between 151st Street and LaPalm Drive;



      (2)   Sunset Avenue between Vine Street and LaPalm Drive;



      (3)   Park Avenue between Vine Street and LaPalm Drive;



      (4)   Lamon Avenue from 155th Street on the south to 153rd
Street on the north;



      (5)   The area from 15300 to 15400 Kilpatrick Avenue;



      (6)   The area on Fern Avenue between Central and Major
Avenues;



      (7)   The area on Chestnut Lane between 151st Street and
Forestview Drive;



      (8)   The area on Willow Lane between 151st Street and
Forestview Drive;



      (9)   The area on Spruce Lane between 151st Street and
Forestview Drive;



      (10)   Oak Avenue Commuter Lot Area Permit Parking Only Zone 2
weekdays from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m. on:



         (a)   Forest Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street
(west side only);



         (b)   Forest Avenue from 160th Street to 162nd Street;



         (c)   Oak Avenue from 160th Street to 162nd Street;



         (d)   Grove Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street;



         (e)   Lavergne Avenue (north and south of 160th to the
terminus);



         (f)   160th Street from Oak to Lavergne (south side);



         (g)   160th Street from Grove Avenue to Laverne Avenue
(north side); and



         (h)   161st Street from Cicero to Forest Avenue;



      (11)   The area on Long Avenue between 151st and Diamond Drive;



      (12)   The area north of 155th Street on Ann Marie Drive,
Betty Ann Lane, Michaele Drive and Natalie Drive is designated as a
residential parking permit only area on school days from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00
p.m.;



      (13)   Creekside Drive and Crescent Lane are designated as
residential parking permit only areas on school days;



      (14)   Kara Court is designated as a residential parking
permit zone;



      (15)   Latrobe from 157th Street to 160th Street; and



      (16)   158th Street from Laramie Avenue; and



      (17)   East side of Laramie Avenue from 158th to 159th and the
north property line of 15742 Laramie to 159th Street on the west side of
Laramie Avenue.



   (B)   Parking permits required.



      (1)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not displaying a
residential parking permit in an area designated as a residential parking
area in division (A)(1) through (3) above, excluding service or delivery
vehicles whose operators are doing business with residents in such areas,
between 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on days when school is in session at Oak
Forest High School.



      (2)   It is unlawful for anyone to park any motor vehicle in
an area designated as a residential parking area in division (A)(4) through
(17) above unless it displays a parking permit.



   (C)   Permit issuance. The city shall issue one residential parking
permit for each vehicle bearing a current City of Oak Forest vehicle sticker
and which is based from a single-family dwelling on the street designated as
a residential parking permit area. The permits shall be restricted to use to
the vehicle for which the permit was issued.



   (D)   In addition, the city shall issue two residential parking
permits for visitors to any residence in the residential parking permit area.
Visitors' parking is limited to the time that the person driving the visiting
vehicle is actually in the residence or on the property being visited.
Additional one-day visitor's permits may be obtained from the city for
special events. Any misuse of any permits shall render them invalid and
additional permits shall not be issued to the person or household which
originally held the same.



   (E)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any service
or delivery vehicle when used to provide services or to make deliveries to
residences within a residential parking permit area, provided that the
parking of the vehicle does not exceed the time the services or deliveries
are being made.



   (F)   Display of permits; limitations.



      (1)   All resident permits shall be displayed on or about the
left side of the front windshield of the vehicle so as to be easily visible
from the outside of the vehicle.



      (2)   The parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a
parking space within the designated residential parking permit area. The
permit shall not authorize the standing or parking of any vehicle in such
places as the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is otherwise
prohibited. Nothing in this chapter shall excuse the observance of any
traffic regulation.



   (G)   (1)   If otherwise allowed by city ordinance the city may
issue a residential parking permit for motor vehicles owned by the resident's
employer and regularly used by the resident. Before issuance of a permit for
such vehicle, the city shall be provided the following proof:



         (a)   Vehicle ownership;



         (b)   A statement from the employer that the vehicle has
been permanently assigned to the resident for his or her use; and



         (c)   As a condition of the resident's employment the
employee is authorized or directed to keep the vehicle in the employee's
possession.



      (2)   Supplemental documentation may be requested by the city.
Nothing in this provision is intended to nor shall it allow the parking of
any vehicles above a "B" classification.



   (H)   Permits shall be issued on an annual basis concurrent with the
issuance of municipal vehicle stickers.



   (I)   Permits shall be permanently displayed in the lower left hand
corner of the vehicle’s rear window.



   (J)   Misrepresentations; duplicate permits.



      (1)   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person
to represent that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by
this chapter when it is not so entitled. The display of a parking permit on a
vehicle not entitled to a parking permit shall constitute a representation.



      (2)   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person
to duplicate or attempt to duplicate, by any means, a parking permit
authorized by this chapter. It shall also be a violation of this chapter for
any person to display on any vehicle a duplicate parking permit.



   (K)   Violation; penalty.



      (1)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in §
10.99 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.



      (2)   In addition, the city expressly incorporates the
provisions of the city towing ordinances, specifically including, but not
limited to, Chapter 74.



(2000 Code, §§ 10.32.010 through 10.32.060)  (Ord. 2676, § 2, passed -
-2002; Am. Ord. 2018-07-0695, passed 7-24-2018; Am. Ord. 2018-08-0700O,
passed - -2018)

STREET AND BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION




§ 90.001  IDOT STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR ROAD AND BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION;
FILE COPIES.



   (A)   There is adopted by and for the city, for the purpose of
prescribing regulations governing construction and material specifications
for streets and other public ways in the city, that certain document known as
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, the most current
edition, prepared and promulgated by the Illinois Department of
Transportation (IDOT), or any successor edition of the aforementioned
publication.



   (B)   At least three copies of that document are on file with the
City Clerk for inspection by the public.



(2000 Code, § 12.04.010)



§ 90.002  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.



   No person shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of
the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, as adopted in
§ 90.001 above, in the repair, improvement or construction of any street or
other public way in the city.



(2000 Code, § 12.04.020)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.003  CONFLICT OF LAWS.



   (A)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, as adopted in
§ 90.001 above, and any provision of these codified ordinances, or any other
local ordinance or resolution, the provision of the Standard Specifications
for Road and Bridge Construction shall control.



   (B)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the document and a provision of any other technical code adopted or referred
to by the city as a standard, the higher or stricter standard shall control.



(2000 Code, § 12.04.030)




SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION




§ 90.015  SIDEWALKS REQUIRED.



   (A)   Public sidewalks shall be installed on all new residential,
commercial and institutional construction.



   (B)   Sidewalks shall also be required where they do not exist on
any remodeling projects and where, in the determination of the Director of
Public Works, the interest of the city would require installation of the
sidewalk.



   (C)   Sidewalks are required on the full street frontage of the lot
and on the side lot frontage on corner lots that border a public street.



   (D)   This section shall also apply to properties governed by the
subdivision regulations.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.010)  (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)



§ 90.016  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall repair or install a public sidewalk without first
obtaining a written permit therefor from the City Building Department.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.020)  (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)  Penalty,
see § 90.999



§ 90.017  PERMIT APPLICATIONS.



   Applications for sidewalk repair or installation permits shall be made
on forms furnished by the city.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.030)



§ 90.018  PERMIT FEES.



   Fees for a sidewalk installation permit shall be in accordance with the
applicable building permit fees and inspection fees as prescribed in Title 15
of this code.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.040)  (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001; Ord.
2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)



§ 90.019  GRADE AND ALIGNMENT STANDARDS.



   Applicants shall comply with the following standard provisions for
sidewalk construction:



   (A)   The minimum width shall be five feet;



   (B)   The minimum thickness shall be five inches with a two-inch
sand or stone cushion;



   (C)   The beginning distance from the property line shall be one
foot;



   (D)   The grade shall follow a line sloping up and away from the top
of the curb at a slope of one-fourth inch per foot; and



   (E)   Concrete shall be subject to a 28-day compression test for a
six-bag mix; three to six percent air entrainment shall be 3,500 psi.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.060)



§ 90.020  VARIANCES.



   (A)   The city may authorize variances from standard sidewalk
provisions set forth in § 90.019 where no curb exists or when unusual
topographical conditions, nature of existing construction or similar factors
would make adherence to the provisions unreasonable.



   (B)   The variance shall only be approved by the Mayor and City
Council.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.070)  (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001; Ord.
2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)



§ 90.021  GRADE AND LINE REQUIRED.



   No sidewalk shall be installed unless a grade and line are established
therefor. If no grade or line is available, a sidewalk may be installed with
an appropriate permit. However, if or when the city establishes a grade and
line, the city may remove, modify or replace the sidewalk to conform to the
grade and line at the city’s expense.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.080)  (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)  Penalty,
see § 90.999



§ 90.022  CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS.



   Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with details and
specifications in § 90.019 above.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.090)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.023  INSPECTIONS.



   All work shall be subject to inspection by the city during construction
and upon completion. A permittee shall notify the city after forms are set,
and no concrete shall be poured or further construction started until the
forms are approved by the city.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.100)  (Ord. 2506, § 2 (part), passed - -2001)



§ 90.024  OCCUPANCY PERMITS.



   (A)   The requirements set forth in this chapter must be met before
an occupancy permit is issued by the city.



   (B)   The Building Commissioner may issue a temporary occupancy
permit, as provided for in the city’s Building Codes and regulations.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.110)  (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)



§ 90.025  WAIVER; PAYMENT TO CITY IN LIEU OF SIDEWALKS.



   (A)   Whenever, in the opinion of the city, the installation of a
public sidewalk would serve no public purpose, that requirement may be waived.



   (B)   If it is determined that the installation of a public sidewalk
is unnecessary, the owner shall, in lieu thereof, pay over to the city an
amount of money, which shall be equal to the current cost of construction of
the sidewalk based on the city’s most recent per lineal foot cost of
sidewalk installation times the lineal width of the subject lot.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.120)  (Ord. 2506, § 2 (part), passed - -2001)



§ 90.026  SIDEWALK FUND.



   The City Treasurer shall establish a sidewalk fund. Moneys paid to the
city pursuant to § 90.025 above shall be deposited and held by the City
Treasurer in the fund and shall be disbursed from time to time for the
purpose of installation, improvement and repair of city sidewalks upon the
direction of Council.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.130)




DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION AND CURB CUTS




§ 90.040  DRIVEWAY REQUIRED.



   (A)   No person shall be granted an occupancy permit under this
chapter without construction of an approved driveway connecting the street to
any garage or automobile storage facility constructed on the property for
which an occupancy permit is being issued.



   (B)   All driveways constructed shall be as specified by the
Building Commissioner.



(Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001; Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed
6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.041  MAXIMUM NUMBER ALLOWED.



   (A)   Only one driveway ingress and egress point onto public or
private right-of-way shall be permitted per lot in any single-family
residence zoning district, except that if any such lot has a minimum front
lot width of 90 feet or more, than a circular drive consisting of two ingress
and egress points onto public or private right-of-way driveway may be allowed.



   (B)   All other uses shall be allowed the number of driveways as
approved by the Mayor and City Council.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.042  DRIVEWAY WIDTHS.



   (A)   The maximum width for driveways for in any single family
residence zoning district shall be 20 feet at the property line and 26 feet
at the street where the garage is located within 30 feet of the property
line.  Garages located greater than 30 feet from the property line and
circle drives shall be ten feet from the property line and 16 feet at the
street.



   (B)   Where a three-car garage is located within 30 feet of the
property line, the driveway shall not exceed 30 feet at the property line and
36 feet at the street.



   (C)   No driveway shall encroach upon any portion of the parkway in
front of the adjoining property.



   (D)   The maximum width for driveways for all other uses shall be
approved by the Mayor and City Council.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006; Am. Ord. 2011-11-0362O, passed
11-22-2011)



§ 90.043  DRIVEWAY GRADES AND CURBS.



   (A)   Driveways shall be level with existing adjoining sidewalk
grades.



   (B)   Where it is necessary to saw, cut or break the existing curb
for the driveway opening, the curb and gutter shall be completely removed and
a new section constructed.



   (C)   Each such driveway shall be constructed and maintained so as
to permit free and unobstructed passage in such a manner as not to interfere
with the proper drainage of the streets.



   (D)   Gradual approaches to the regular sidewalk grade shall be one
inch above the gutter slab.



   (E)   The slope of the driveway and to the approaches thereto shall
not exceed a six percent slope in any direction.



   (F)   Each such driveway shall be constructed and maintained so that
its surface, at the point of crossing any sidewalk pavement, shall be flush
with the adjoining sections of the sidewalk.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.044  CONNECTION TO COLLECTOR OR ARTERIAL STREETS.



   (A)   Driveways connecting to collector or arterial streets must
provide an on-site turn around.



   (B)   Where a lot fronts both a local street and a collector or
arterial street, no driveways shall be installed along the property line of
the lot that fronts the arterial or collector street



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.045  PLACEMENT OF DRIVEWAY.



   At no time shall any portion of a driveway be closer to a side property
line than one foot.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.046  REMOVAL OF PARKWAY TREES.



   (A)   At no time shall any parkway tree be removed to allow for the
installation or portion thereof, of any driveway; provided, however, that the
property owner may request in writing that the Mayor and City Council waive
this prohibition upon a finding of undue hardship.



   (B)   Where an undue hardship is determined, in the sole and
absolute discretion, by the Mayor and City Council, this provision may be
waived, for removal of the tree.



   (C)   The Mayor and City Council may require that the property owner:



      (1)   Reimburse the city for the current fair market value of
the tree that is removed; or



      (2)   Replace the parkway tree with the same or similar
species with approximately the same caliper width.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.047  IMPERVIOUS SURFACE LIMITATION.



   Any new driveway, or additions to an existing driveway shall conform to
the drainage requirements as set forth in §§ 152.30 through 152.37 of this
code.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.048  DRIVEWAYS OVER DRAINAGE DITCHES; CULVERT REQUIRED.



   No person shall construct or maintain a private drive or roadway from
any public street in the city over or across any drainage ditch now or
hereafter existing, unless he or she installs and maintains a culvert
thereunder in accordance with this chapter.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.049  CULVERT PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall install a culvert under any private drive or roadway
unless a permit therefor is first applied for and obtained from the Director
of Public Works.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.050  GRADE AND SIZE.



   Upon an application for a permit required by § 90.049, the Director of
Public Works or the City Engineer shall forthwith establish the grade for and
prescribe the size of the proposed culvert.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.051  MATERIALS.



   Every culvert shall be of a size determined by the Director of Public
Works to be adequate to permit the free flow of water in a ditch and shall be
corrugated galvanized steel, reinforced concrete, cast iron or such other
material that meets with the approval of the Director of Public Works.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.052  INSTALLATION.



   Every culvert shall be installed in conformity with the flow of a ditch
and in a manner prescribed by the Director of Public Works so it will not
impede the normal flow of water in the ditch and so there will be no stagnant
water standing or retained behind it.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.053  CHANGE OF GRADE PROHIBITED.



   No person installing a culvert shall change the grade of the ditch in
which the culvert is being installed from the grade established and
prescribed by the Director of Public Works or the City Engineer.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.054  REFUSE IN CULVERTS; OBSTRUCTIONS TO WATER FLOW.



   Any person who maintains a private drive or roadway across any ditch
into premises owned or occupied by him or her shall keep the culvert
thereunder clean and free from all refuse and matter which may impede the
free flow of water in the ditch.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.055  NOTICE TO CLEAN; CLEANING BY CITY.



   (A)   If a culvert becomes plugged or clogged, the owner or occupant
of the property into which a private drive or roadway over the culvert leads
shall be notified to clean the same within 24 hours after notification. The
notification shall be made in writing and may be served by delivering the
same to the owner or occupant personally or by posting the same on the
premises.



   (B)   If the owner or occupant fails to clean the culvert within 24
hours after notification, the city shall cause the culvert to be cleaned and
shall charge all expenses of such cleaning to the owner or occupant.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.056 APPLICATION TO EXISTING CULVERTS.



   If an existing culvert under any private drive or roadway fails to
comply with this chapter, or impedes the free flow of water in the ditch in
which it is installed, the owner or occupant of the property into which the
drive or roadway leads, upon notice from the city, shall install a proper
culvert in accordance with this chapter.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.057  REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT BY CITY.



   Any existing culvert that has been approved as to size, material and
location by the city and any such culvert hereafter approved as to size,
material and location by the city, which subsequently is ordered to be
removed by the city, shall be removed and replaced at the sole expense of the
city.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.058  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall repair or install a driveway, or any addition to an
existing driveway, without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the
City Building Department.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.059  CONCRETE DRIVES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.



   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide
specifications for materials and construction of concrete drives in all
residentially zoned districts.



   (B)   General specifications. Materials and construction for
residential drives shall conform to § 406, Standard Specifications for Road
and Bridge Construction, Illinois Department of Transportation, most current
edition,, or any successor edition thereto, except as stated in divisions (C)
through (E) below.



   (C)   Materials.



      (1)   Aggregate. The stone aggregate shall conform to § 704
of the standard specifications, except as follows:



         (a)   The gradation of the stone shall be CA6 or CA7,
that is “State Road Mix;”



         (b)   No pea gravel, chips or tunnel rock shall be
allowed; and



         (c)   No slag shall be used; only limestone is permitted.



      (2)   Concrete. Concrete driveways shall be constructed with a
minimum of six sacks of cement per cubic yard. The minimum compressive
strength of 4,000 psi at 28 days, maximum size aggregate of one inch, air
entrainment of 6% plus 1%, maximum slump of four inches, maximum water
content including moisture in the aggregate of six gallons per sack of
cement, and all concrete shall contain a water-reducing admixture with no
reduction in cement content permitted.



   (D)   Thickness.



      (1)   Aggregate base. The aggregate base shall be a minimum of
two inches thick.



      (2)   Concrete. The concrete for a driveway, other than the
apron, shall be a minimum of four inches thick with reinforcement or five
full inches thick without reinforcement. The apron shall consist of a full
seven inches with no reinforcement.



   (E)   Forms. Side forms shall be of lumber of not less than two
inches nominal thickness or steel of equal rigidity. The minimum depth of the
side forms shall be equal to the driveway thickness. No two-inch by four-inch
lumber forms shall be permitted. Forms shall be held securely in place by
stakes or braces with the top edge true to line and grade.



   (F)   Expansion joints. Expansion joints of the thickness specified
below shall consist of a premolded filler strip with the top strip placed
one-fourth inch below the surface of the driveway. One-half inch thick
expansion joints shall be provided at the junction of the driveway apron and
the sidewalk and at the junction of the driveway apron and the curb.



   (G)   Backfill. After the concrete has been cured, forms shall be
removed and the space near the edges of the driveway shall be backfilled to
the required elevation and the material shall be compacted until firm and the
surface evenly graded.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.060  ASPHALT DRIVES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.



   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide
specifications for materials and construction of asphalt drives in
residentially zoned districts.



   (B)   General specifications. Materials and construction for
residential drives shall conform to § 406, Standard Specifications for Road
and Bridge Construction, Illinois Department of Transportation, adopted
October 1, 1983, as amended, except as stated in divisions (C) to (E) below.



   (C)   Materials.



      (1)   Aggregate. The stone aggregate shall conform to § 704
of the standard specifications, except as follows:



         (a)   The gradation of the stone shall be CA6, that is
“State Road Mix;”



         (b)   No pea gravel, chips or tunnel rock shall be
allowed; and



         (c)   No slag shall be used; only limestone is permitted.



      (2)   Bituminous asphalt. The bituminous asphalt surface
course shall be Class 1, Mixture C, modified in accordance with §§ 406 and
704.03 of the standard specifications, except that CA16 aggregate gradation
shall be used. The asphalt cement shall be AC WO to 120, that is a “State
Fine Mix.”



   (D)   Thickness.



      (1)   Aggregate base. The crushed stone aggregate base shall
be eight inches thick.



      (2)   Bituminous asphalt surface course. The surface course
shall be two inches thick.



   (E)   Construction.



      (1)   Sub-base preparation.



         (a)   The overdig of the foundation in front of a garage
door shall be backfilled with crushed stone. No clay or black dirt shall be
used as backfill. The backfill shall be hand tamped.



         (b)   The drive area shall be cleared of all
construction debris, drywall, wood, loose clay and black dirt. Should the
sub-base need to be brought to grade, no clay backfill is allowed. Any
sub-base overdig shall be filled with stone.



         (c)   The sub-base shall be rolled and compacted to a
distance of one foot beyond the width of the drive. The sub-base must be dry,
so that no sub-base material sticks to the roller.



      (2)   Aggregate base. The crushed stone aggregate shall be
placed in two four-inch lifts, compacted after each lift. The contractor
shall wet each lift before rolling.



      (3)   Asphalt surface course.



         (a)   The asphalt surface shall be placed in one
two-inch lift.



         (b)   The surface shall be rolled smooth such as to
leave no roller marks.



         (c)   Care shall be taken to hand tamp and roll next to
walks and garage apron areas.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.061  GRAVEL DRIVES.



   No existing gravel driveway shall be enlarged, altered or otherwise
changed without the property owner:



   (A)   Obtaining a permit, as required by the chapter; and



   (B)   Constructing any such enlargement, alteration or change in
conformity with the standards set forth in this chapter.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



§ 90.062  APRONS AND ACCESSWAYS.



   (A)   Aprons or other accessways constructed from the edge of the
pavement of a curbed city street across public and/or private property to
serve residential, commercial or other purposes can be of asphalt, concrete
or brick paver materials. Any material installed in the apron of other than
plain concrete or plain asphalt will be installed at the owner's risk.  An
apron or accessway of an alternate material such as brick paver, stamped,
colored or aggregate concrete or stamped asphalt will require a waiver from
the owner releasing and absolving the city of any responsibility or liability
in connection with the apron or accessway.  The waiver must be signed by
owner at time of building permit procurement.  New driveway and apron or
replacement of driveway and apron shall be of the same material.



   (B)   The concrete and any supporting material shall conform with
the concrete specifications as listed in § 90.059 above. Concrete shall not
be poured prior to inspection.



   (C)   The asphalt and any supporting material shall conform with the
asphalt specifications as listed in § 90.060 above.  Asphalt shall not be
poured prior to inspection.



   (D)   The brick pavers and any supporting material shall conform
with ASTM C 902 Standard Specification for Pedestrian and Light Traffic
Paving Brick.  Brick pavers shall not be installed prior to inspection.



   (E)   Public sidewalk construction must follow § 90.015 above.
Public sidewalks must be of plain concrete and separate of apron and driveway.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006; Am. Ord. 2010-08-0303O, passed
8-10-2010)



§ 90.063  CURB CUTS.



   (A)   No person shall cut, break or change the stoop or slope of any
curb in the city without the prior approval of the Director of Public Works.



   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of this section shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or
bonds.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)




EXCAVATIONS




§ 90.070  PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION AND FEE.



   (A)   No person shall make any opening, excavation or tunnel in any
public street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or other public place in the city
without first obtaining a permit therefor.



   (B)   Applications for such a permit shall be made to the City Clerk
and shall specify the intended location and purpose of the excavation.



   (C)   The City Clerk shall immediately notify the Director of Public
Works of the application for the permit.



   (D)   The fee for the permit is $100.



   (E)   The city may waive this fee upon written request provided that
the excavation is in the best interests of the City of Oak Forest.



(2000 Code, § 12.16.010)  (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), 2001)  Penalty, see §
90.999



§ 90.071  RESTORATION OF STREETS AND SURFACES; CASH DEPOSIT.



   (A)   Each applicant shall restore a street, alley, sidewalk,
parkway or other public place, and the surface thereof, to the condition that
existed before an opening, excavation or tunnel was made.



   (B)   The applicant shall do all necessary backfilling or cause the
same to be done.



   (C)   All backfilling shall be done with care and caution and only
bank or lake sand shall be used as backfill. After the backfilling has been
properly done, any material excavated or not used shall be removed from the
location of the excavation to the places as the Director of Public Works
directs.



   (D)   In restoring the street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or other
public place, the city may use its own employees and equipment and make
reasonable charges therefor, or it may engage the services of other persons
and equipment and charge the cost thereof to the applicant.



   (E)   Applicants not restoring a street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or
other public place shall be liable for all restoration costs and shall be
fined $100 per day from the date specified in written notice from the city.



(2000 Code, § 12.16.020)  (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001)



§ 90.072  SUPERVISION BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.



   All openings, excavations, tunnels, refills and resurfacing in the city
shall be made under the supervision of the Director of Public Works.



(2000 Code, § 12.16.030)  Penalty, see § 90.999




STREET AND SIDEWALK USE REGULATIONS




§ 90.085  SOLICITATION OF FUNDS BY CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS.



   (A)   All religious or charitable organizations seeking to solicit
funds on streets in the city must hereafter this date complete a permit
application available at City Hall or on the city's web site. This permit
application must be completed in its entirety, dated and signed by an officer
of the religious or charitable organization seeking to solicit funds in the
city.



   (B)   Any religious or charitable organization seeking to solicit
funds on streets in the city must also provide a not-for-profit certificate
issued by the Attorney General of the State of Illinois, as well as a
certificate of insurance with an appropriate level of insurance as noted on
the permit application.



   (C)   The religious or charitable organization must submit the
permit application, not-for-profit certificate and certificate of insurance
to the Mayor or his or her designee. All solicitation on public roadways in
the city must comply with the following provisions:



      (1)   A soliciting person or agency shall be registered with
the Illinois Attorney General as a charitable organization, as provided by
ILCS Ch. 225, Act 460, §§ 1 et seq., An Act to Regulate Solicitations and
Collection of Funds for Charitable Purposes. The soliciting person or agency
must be engaged in statewide fund raising activity and will be liable for any
injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally
related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.



      (2)   No person shall stand on a roadway for the purpose of
soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except after
receiving a fully executed permit from the city.



      (3)   No religious or charitable organization will be given a
permit to solicit for more than two  12- hour periods on roadways in the
city in any calendar year (January - December).



      (4)   No more than one permit shall be issued by the city for
the same date at the same intersection. Applications will be treated on a
first come, first served basis.



      (5)   Solicitations shall only be conducted at traffic control
intersections when traffic has come to a full stop during the hours of
daylight, but in no event earlier than 7:00 a.m. in the morning or later than
7:00 p.m. in the evening.



      (6)   Any person engaged in the act of soliciting on a public
roadway shall be 16 years of age or more and wear a high visibility yellow or
orange safety vest and clear identification of the organization undertaking
the solicitation.



      (7)   Solicitors may only solicit an behalf of a permitted
organization and such solicitation may only occur during a charitable
solicitation event.



      (8)   Solicitors shall not approach a moving vehicle or one
that does not have a window down and an occupant has given some sign of
assent to approach.



      (9)   Solicitors shall only enter the roadway while the
traffic signal for that lane is red and shall not enter the roadway while
traffic is moving.



      (10)   No solicitor shall at any time enter or remain in the
traveled portion of the roadway or solicit in a manner which impedes the flow
of traffic.



      (11)   No person shall solicit in the public right-of-way at
any time or place not designated in the application permit under which the
person is conducting the solicitation.



      (12)   Any violation of the provisions of this section or
extraordinarily adverse weather conditions will constitute a reason for the
city to cease all soliciting activities.



   (D)   The permit application, not-for-profit certificate and
certificate of insurance must be submitted to the Mayor's office at least 30
calendar days before the requested date(s) of solicitation. The city will
have seven calendar days to either approve or reject the request for
solicitation.



   (E)   The provisions of this application process will encourage
religious and charitable organizations to make their plans to solicit funds
on roadways in the city well in advance of their requested date(s). It will
also allow proper processing of requests by the municipality, afford an equal
opportunity to all those religious and charitable organizations that wish to
solicit funds in the city, and promote activities that result in the safer
solicitation of funds on crowded public roadways.



(2000 Code, § 12.20.020) (Am. Ord. 2011-09-0352O, passed 9-27-2011) 
Penalty, see § 90.999



§ 90.086  ENCROACHMENTS ON ROUTE 50 (CICERO AVENUE).



   No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place,
maintain or construct any structure that encroaches upon the state
right-of-way on Route 50 (Cicero Avenue) within the limits of the city.



(2000 Code, § 12.20.030)  Penalty, see § 90.999



TREES AND PARKWAYS



§ 90.100  PURPOSE.



   (A)   The purpose of this subchapter is to provide for the proper
parkway standards and establishment of new trees, the protection and
maintenance of existing trees and the timely removal of hazardous or
infectious diseased trees on both public and private property.



   (B)   It is further intended to balance the property rights of
individual property owners with those of the overall health, safety and
welfare interests of the city.  Trees enhance and preserve the air quality
of the city through the filtering effect of trees on air pollutants, reduce
noise within the city through the baffle and barrier effect of trees on the
spread of noise, reduce topsoil erosion through the soil retention effect of
tree roots, reduce energy consumption through the wind break and shade
effects, provide nesting areas for birds and other wildlife which in turn
assist in the control of insects, reduce storm water runoff and the costs
associated therewith, replenish ground water supplies and protect and
increase property values.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.101  RESIDENTIAL PARKWAY STANDARDS.



   All uses which require site plan or special use approval shall install
and maintain trees along any parkway which abuts the perimeter of the
property.



   (A)   The parkway shall be grass or low ground cover, except where
covered by driveway pavement. A minimum of one parkway tree per 40 feet of
frontage is required for all development.



   (B)   The use of loose stone, rock, or gravel is prohibited on
public parkways.



   (C)   Other than trees, no landscaping shall be taller than two feet.



   (D)   No tree or bush with a mature height of more than two feet
shall be planted within a distance of 33 feet of any street corner, measured
from the point of the nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines as extended. 
No tree shall be planted closer than six feet of any fire hydrant.



   (E)   Trees shall be planted on the center line of parkways or as
close to five feet from the sidewalk as possible and located so as not to
interfere with overhead wires or traffic or pedestrian safety.



   (F)   A minimum parkway width of four feet is required for trees in
a parkway.



   (G)   Wherever feasible, parkway trees shall be planted on the
public parkway and not on the private property side of the sidewalk.



   (H)   Parkway trees shall consist of shorter trees if overhead
utilities exist.  Otherwise, taller trees are required as shown in the
following list.  No species shall comprise more than 30% of the overall
parkway tree count for new development.  A mixture of trees shall be planted
whenever feasible.



   (I)   No person shall attach any object to a parkway tree.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.102  TREE REMOVAL PERMIT.



   No person shall remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any street,
parkway or other public place without first securing a permit from the
Department of Public Works. Any permit authorizing removal may be subject to
such conditions as the Director of Public Works or his or her designee may
deem necessary or appropriate to minimize damage to other trees or vegetation
on a site, and may include the installation of protective fencing.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.103  TREE DETERMINATION.



   The city shall designate a specified list of trees to be planted within
the city limits, only trees on this list have been approved.  The Public
Works Director or his or her designee may from time to time allow deviation
from this list at his or her sole discretion.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)

§ 90.105  NUISANCE TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.



   The city, in accordance with the law, shall have the right to cause the
removal of any dead, diseased, or trees that are deemed a nuisance on private
property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and
property, or harbor insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat
to other trees within the city.  The city will notify in writing the owners
of such trees. Removal is the responsibility of said owners and shall be done
by the owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service
of notice or such other time as may be agreed upon by the city and the
property owner. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such
provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and file a
lien against the property for the amount of the costs of removal.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.106  PRUNING, RIGHT-OF-WAY CLEARANCE OF PRIVATE TREES.



   Every owner of any privately owned tree overhanging any street or
right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches
shall not obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there
shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or
sidewalk.  Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous
privately owned trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace
to the safety of the public. The city, in accordance with the law, shall have
the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes
with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or
interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.107  VIOLATIONS OF TREE REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Whoever violates this subchapter, in addition to any other
fines, or fees, shall be subject to the following provisions:



      (1)   Fines: first offense, $500; second offense, $1,000;
third and subsequent offense, $2,500.



      (2)   All violations that are committed by the same person or
any firm controlled by such person shall be counted, regardless of whether or
not the violations occur at the same time. Any finding or plea of guilty or
plea of "no contest" upon a citation shall be deemed a violation.



   (B)   Any entity or person who injures a public tree shall be held
responsible for the costs of repairs, such as pruning or cabling, if the
injured tree will not die as a result of such injuries. In cases where the
tree has been damaged beyond repair and cannot remain in the public
right-of-way, the entity or person responsible for the damage shall remove
the tree and stump at their own costs, or if the tree is an immediate hazard,
the entity or person shall pay the cost the city incurs in its removal.



   (C)   In addition to any fines that may be assessed for violation of
this section, the person shall pay to the city a sum equal to the value or
partial value of the tree lost as a result of the violation. The value or
partial value of the tree lost shall be as determined by the Department of
Public Works using the most current edition of the Guide for Plant Appraisal
prepared by the Council of Tree and Landscape Appraisers, and edited,
published and copyrighted by the International Society of Arboriculture.
Various factors used in the tree value calculations for northern Illinois
shall be obtained from the most current edition of the Species Ratings and
Appraisal Factors for Illinois prepared by the Illinois Arborist Association.
The collection of this fee shall be used by the city for the replacement of
the damaged or destroyed tree. Any remaining funds after the damaged or
destroyed tree has been replaced will be deposited into a tree planting fund
to be administered by the Director of Public Works.



   (D)   If the entity or person cannot pay the fines and fees, a lien
shall be placed against the property.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



§ 90.108  INTERFERENCE WITH THE CITY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with
the city or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting,
cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees,
park trees, or dead, nuisance, or diseased trees on private grounds.



(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)



HONORARY DESIGNATION OF STREETS



§ 90.120  REQUEST.



   (A)   Every request for the honorary designation of a street shall
be presented in writing to the City Clerk.



   (B)   All requests must include the following information:



      (1)   Name of the person, organization or entity to be honored;



      (2)   The humanitarian, civic, community or other reasons
which make the honor appropriate; and



      (3)   The name, address and phone number of the person
submitting the request.



   (C)   The request shall also be accompanied by either a petition
signed by occupants of at least 75 residential locations within the city or a
memorandum submitted by at least three aldermen or the Mayor.



(2000 Code, § 12.28.010)  (Ord. 2632 § 1, passed --2002)



§ 90.121  PROCESS.



   After receipt and review of the application to determine compliance
with the request criteria the City Clerk shall forward the request to the
City Council for consideration and approval.



(2000 Code, § 12.28.020)  (Ord. 2632, § 2, passed --2002)



§ 90.122  DURATION.



   (A)   If approved, the honorary designation shall be placed and
maintained until the end of the calendar year following approval.



   (B)   At the end of this time the honorary sign shall be removed and
delivered to the family of the honored party.



(2000 Code, § 12.28.030)  (Ord. 2632 § 3, passed --2002)



§ 90.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is provided shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of this §§ 90.001 through 90.003 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her
building bond or bonds.



(2000 Code, § 12.04.040)



   (C)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of §§ 90.015 through 90.026 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her
building bond or bonds.



(2000 Code, § 12.08.140)



   (D)   Whoever violated or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of §§ 90.040 through 90.055 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her
building bond or bonds.



(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)



   (E)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions
of §§ 90.070 through 90.072 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her
building bond or bonds.



(2000 Code, § 12.16.040)
