FIRE PREVENTION CODE




§ 94.01  ADOPTION BY REFERENCE; FILE COPIES.



   (A)   There is adopted by and for the city, for the purpose of
prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property
from fire or explosion, the Fire Prevention Code, recommended by the American
Insurance Association, being particularly the 1976 edition thereof, as
amended through November, 1982, save and except for such portions as may be
amended or repealed in this chapter, and the National Fire Codes, recommended
by the National Fire Protection Association, being particularly the most
current edition thereof,  or any successor edition of the aforementioned
publication, save and except for such portions as may be amended or repealed
in this chapter.



   (B)   At least three copies of those codes are on file with the City
Clerk for inspection by the public.



   (C)   The codes, together with the provisions of this chapter of
these codified ordinances, shall constitute the Fire Prevention Code of the
city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.010)



§ 94.02  DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   Wherever the word MUNICIPALITY is used in the A.I.A. Fire
Prevention Code, it shall mean the City of Oak Forest.



   (B)   Wherever the term CORPORATION COUNSEL is used in that code, it
shall mean the City Attorney.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.020)



§ 94.03  BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION; AUTHORITY OF FIRE CHIEF.



   (A)   This Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the Bureau of
Fire Prevention in the Fire Department of the city.



   (B)   A report of the Bureau shall be made annually and transmitted
to the Mayor. The report shall contain all proceedings under this Fire
Prevention Code, with such statistics as the Chief decides to include
therein. The Chief shall also recommend any amendment to this code which, in
his or her judgment, is desirable.



   (C)   The Chief may request and shall receive, so far as may be
necessary, in the discharge of his or her duties, the assistance and
cooperation of other officials of the municipality.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.030)



§ 94.04  AMENDMENTS TO CODE.



   The A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code, adopted  in § 94.01 above is amended
as follows:



   (A)   A.I.A. § 1.2. Application of Code is amended by adding
thereto the following:



      c.    All existing buildings, regardless of occupancy,
construction or size, shall conform to this Fire Prevention Code if any type
of building permit is issued. This Fire Prevention Code includes remodeling,
additions, repairs or other alterations.



   (B)   A.I.A. § 11.3. Lighting of Exit-ways is amended by adding
thereto the following:



Adequate emergency lighting shall be installed and maintained in buildings of
all types of occupancy, except in single-family dwellings.



   (C)   A.I.A. Section 14.4. Automatic Sprinkler Systems is amended as
follows:



      g.    OTHER INSTALLATIONS.



         (1)   An approved complete automatic sprinkler system
shall be installed in all buildings which have a gross area on any floor of
more than 7,000 square feet and in all buildings which are either two stories
in height or twenty-seven feet in height, when such types of buildings are
used or intended for the following uses or occupancies: assembly,
educational, industrial, institutional, mercantile, storage or sale of
combustible goods.



         (2)   An approved complete automatic sprinkler system
shall be installed in all buildings, regardless of type of construction, use
or occupancy, which exceed either three stories or forty feet in height.



         (3)   An approved complete automatic sprinkler system
and standpipe system shall be installed in all buildings, regardless of type
of construction, that are used or occupied as a hospital, infirmary, nursing
home, day care center, orphanage, sheltered care home, home for the aged or
child care or custodial care facility.



         (4)   An approved automatic sprinkler system shall be
installed in all apartment buildings, condominiums, townhouses, motels,
hotels or other residential buildings with more than twenty-four units and/or
more than three stories. Sprinklers shall cover all areas except living units.



      h.    GROSS FLOOR AREA DEFINED: For purposes of this section,
“gross floor area” means the ground area of the buildings. The area
included within the surrounding exterior walls of a building shall include
roof overhangs and extensions and all enclosed extensions. Areas of a
building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included within the
building area if such areas are included with the horizontal projection of
the roof or floor above. Interior walls, including fire walls and party
walls, shall not be considered as walls which divide a structure into two or
more separate buildings, but structures containing such interior walls shall
be considered as one building for the purposes of this section.



      i.    INSTALLATION OF AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER SYSTEMS: All
automatic sprinkler systems shall be installed so as to provide reasonable
safety to persons and property and in accordance with all applicable
provisions of this Fire Prevention Code and other applicable codes and
ordinances of the city.



      j.    APPROVAL OF PLANS FOR AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER SYSTEMS: All
plans for automatic sprinkler systems shall be initially approved by the
Insurance Service Office of Illinois, the Industrial Risk Insurance
Association or an insurance organization having interest in the building. The
builders, building owners or their agents shall then submit the initially
approved and stamped plans for proposed sprinkler systems to the Fire
Prevention Officer of the Bureau of Fire Prevention for additional approval.
Such plans shall show the size, capacity and location of all sprinkler heads,
pumps, tanks or pipes, and any other apparatus which is to be used in
connection with such sprinkler systems. Such plans, when approved by the Fire
Prevention Officer, shall also be stamped by him or her to that effect before
such system is installed. The Fire Prevention Officer shall not have
authority to determine what sprinkler systems shall be installed, but only to
approve plans for such proposed systems.



      k.    HYDRANTS: Standard fire hydrants shall be provided
within 300 feet of all exposed parts of all buildings.



   (D)   A.I.A. Section 27.1. Definitions is amended to read as follows:



      a.   “Decorative material” includes all such material as
curtains, draperies, streamers, surface coverings applied over the building
interior finish for decoration, acoustical or other effect, and cloth,
cotton, batting, straw, vines, leaves, trees and plastics used for decorative
effect. The term also includes floor coverings and all materials one-fortieth
of an inch or less in thickness applied directly to and adhering tightly to a
noncombustible base. All such material shall be listed by Underwriters’
Laboratories, Inc. or an equivalent testing laboratory (approved by the Fire
Prevention Officer).



      b.   “Place of assembly” means a room or space used for
assembly or educational occupancy for 100 or more occupants or which has a
floor area of 1,500 square feet or more used for such purposes. Such room or
space shall include any similar occupied connecting room or space in the same
story, or in a story above or below, where entrance is common to the rooms or
space.



   (E)   A.I.A. Section 27.4. Pyroxylin Coated Fabric is amended to
read as follows:



      Pyroxylin coated materials shall not be used as a surface
covering on any interior finish or fixed furnishings.



   (F)   A.I.A. Section 28.5. Hot Ashes and Other Dangerous Materials
is amended to read as follows:



      In any residential building, other than a single-family home, no
person shall use a barbeque grill or hibachi on a porch or balcony.



   (G)   A.I.A. Article 32 - EARLY WARNING DETECTION is added to read
as follows:



      Section 32.1. Systems in Multiple Dwellings.



      All multiple dwellings, such as hotels, motels, apartments,
condominiums, etc., shall have an early warning fire and smoke detection
system. The system shall consist of products of combustion detectors in the
corridors, on top of the stairwells and in tenant storage areas, Thermal
detectors shall be placed in all boiler rooms, janitorial closets, mechanical
equipment rooms, workshop areas and laundry areas. Each floor shall have at
least two manual fire stations placed near the stairs or exit. Each floor
shall have at least two audible fire alarm devices.



      Section 32.2. Approval Required.



      The system described in Section 32.1 shall be labeled and
approved by Factory Mutual Insurance Company, Underwriters’ Laboratories,
Inc. and all local governing bodies, before installation.



      Section 32.3. Systems in Single-Family Dwellings.



      All single-family homes shall be equipped with early warning fire
and smoke detection systems. The system shall consist of products of
combustion detectors on each floor. They shall be labeled and approved by
Factory Mutual Insurance Company and Underwriters’ Laboratories, Inc.,
before installation. The Bureau of Fire Prevention shall also approve
detectors and the location of the same. Instructions to homeowners shall be
given at the time of occupancy.



      Section 32.4. Systems in Buildings of More than 3,000 Square Feet.



      All other buildings with more than 3,000 square feet of floor
area, regardless of construction or occupancy, shall be equipped with early
warning fire and smoke detection systems, unless equipped with approved
automatic sprinkler systems with automatic flow alarms.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.040)



§ 94.05  AUTHORITY TO MODIFY ADOPTED CODES.



   (A)   The Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention may modify any of
the provisions of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code and the National Fire Codes
upon application, in writing, by an owner or lessee, or his or her duly
authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of
carrying out the strict letter of those codes, provided that the intent of
the codes shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice
done.



   (B)   The particulars of that modification, when granted or allowed,
and the decision of the Chief thereon, shall be entered upon the records of
the Fire Department and a signed copy shall be furnished to the applicant.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.050)



§ 94.06  STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING AGENTS.



   The limits referred to in § 12.5b of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code,
in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are
established as the entire corporate limits of the city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.060)



§ 94.07  MANUFACTURE AND STORAGE OF FIREWORKS.



   The limits referred to in § 13.3a of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code,
in which the manufacture and storage of fireworks are prohibited, are
established as the entire corporate limits of the city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.070)



§ 94.08  STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS IN OUTSIDE ABOVEGROUND TANKS.



   (A)   The limits referred to in § 16.22a of the A.I.A. Fire
Prevention Code, in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground
tanks is prohibited, are established as the entire corporate limits of the
city.



   (B)   The limits referred to in § 16.61 of the A.I.A. Fire
Prevention Code, in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible
liquids are prohibited, are established as the entire corporate limits of the
city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.080)



§ 94.09  BULK STORAGE OF LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS.



   The limits referred to in § 21.6a of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code,
in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are
established as the entire corporate limits of the city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.090)



§ 94.10  ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING AGENTS.



   The routes referred to in § 12.7o of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code
for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are established as
follows.



   (A)   (1)   The route for interstate shipments is Illinois
Interstate 57 only.



      (2)   No stopping or parking of vehicles of interstate
shipments shall be allowed within the limits of the city, except for the
purpose of inspection by the Bureau of Fire Prevention to ensure compliance
with this Fire Prevention Code.



   (B)   The route for intrastate shipments shall be determined by the
Fire Chief at the time of issuance of a permit, as the route will differ
depending on the destination of the vehicle within the city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.100)



§ 94.11  ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS AND DANGEROUS
ARTICLES.



   The routes referred to in § 20.14 of the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code
for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles
are established as follows.



   (A)   (1)   The route for interstate shipments is Illinois
Interstate 57 only.



      (2)   No stopping or parking of vehicles of interstate
shipments shall be allowed within the limits of the city, except for the
purpose of inspection by the Bureau of Fire Prevention to ensure compliance
with this Fire Prevention Code.



   (B)   The route for intrastate shipments shall be determined by the
Fire Chief at the time of issuance of a permit, as the route will differ
depending on the destination of the vehicle within the city.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.110)

§ 94.13  ELEVATORS.



   In all buildings in which elevators are installed, at least one
elevator shall be of a reasonable size to accommodate a stretcher for the
purpose of rescue or ambulance duties.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.130)



§ 94.14  CONNECTION OF FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS TO CENTRAL FIRE ALARMS
INDICATOR STATION.



   All required fire protection systems shall be connected to the central
fire alarms indicator station authorized and supervised by the city. No
automatic dialers or similar devices will be allowed.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.140)



§ 94.15  NON-ENERGIZED WIRING OUTLETS.



   (A)   All buildings which exceed two stories in height shall have
non-energized wiring from ground level with three-prong male twist outlets at
the base and three-prong female twist-lock outlets at each floor level so as
to provide at least one such outlet in all stairwells at each floor level and
not more than 100 feet of travel distance from any point at each floor level
to at least one such outlet.



   (B)   All wiring shall be No. 8 and shall be installed in accordance
with the electrical requirements of the Building and Housing Code.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.150)



§ 94.16  PLACEMENT OF GRILLS AND SIMILAR DEVICES.



   (A)   No person shall be allowed to use, maintain or place any
barbecue grill, Hibachi or manufactured portable fireplace or fire pit on any
balcony or porch in any multifamily unit or commercial building.



   (B)   Nothing in this section is intended to, nor prohibits, the
safe use of barbecue grills or other similar devices on either of
single-family residences or townhouses.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.160)  (Ord. 2326 § 1, passed - -1998)  Penalty, see §
94.99



§ 94.17  USE OF PORTABLE FIREPLACES/FIRE PITS.



   No portable fireplace or fire pit shall be allowed on other than
single-family residences. The use of manufactured portable fireplaces/fire
pits is further restricted as follows.



   (A)   All manufactured portable fireplaces/fire pits shall be
expressly approved by the Underwriter’s Laboratory or any successor
organization. No devices other than those approved by the Underwriter’s
Laboratory shall be allowed.



   (B)   Every portable fireplace or fire pit shall be placed at least
ten feet from any structure.



   (C)   No portable fireplace or fire pit shall be used on the
interior of any structure.



   (D)   In addition to all other restrictions, the portable fireplace
or fire pit shall be used only in well-ventilated areas.



   (E)   Only felled and split lots or manufactured logs shall be
burned in the portable fireplace or fire pit. The burning of treated or
dimensional lumber, trash, rubbish, papers, leaves, yard waste and similar
substances are prohibited.



   (F)   Every portable fireplace and fire pit shall be safely,
securely and entirely placed on a fully noncombustible surface i.e.,
concrete, asphalt, stone or rock.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.170)  (Ord. 2326 § 2, passed - -1998)



§ 94.18  NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH REQUIRE PERMITS.



   (A)   The Mayor, the Fire Chief and the Chief of the Bureau of Fire
Prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving
affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or
occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated
in the A.I.A. Fire Prevention Code and the National Fire Codes.



   (B)   The Chief of the Bureau shall post the list in a conspicuous
place in his or her office and shall distribute copies thereof to interested
persons.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.180)



§ 94.19  APPEALS.



   Whenever the Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention disapproves an
application or refuses to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed
that the provisions of this Fire Prevention Code do not apply or that the
true intent and meaning of this Fire Prevention Code have been misconstrued
or wrongly interpreted, the applicant is permitted to appeal from the
decision of the Chief to the Mayor and Council within 30 days from the date
of the decision.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.190)



§ 94.20  VIOLATIONS.



   No person shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of
this Fire Prevention Code, or violate or fail to comply with any order made
hereunder, or build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications
or plans submitted and approved hereunder, or any certificate or permit
issued hereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or fail to comply
with such an order as affirmed or modified by the Mayor and Council or by a
court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.200)  Penalty, see § 94.99




INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE




§ 94.35  ADOPTION OF CODE.



   That a certain document, three copies of which are on file in the
office of the City Clerk of the City of Oak Forest, being marked and
designated as the International Fire Code, 2009 Edition, as published by the
International Code Council, be and is adopted as the Fire Code of the City of
Oak Forest, in the State of Illinois regulating and governing the
safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising
from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and
devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy
of buildings and premises as provided in this section; providing for the
issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the
regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the Fire Code on
file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of Oak Forest are referred
to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this subchapter
with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in
§§ 94.36 through 94.37.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.010)  (Ord. 2914 § 1, passed - -2005; Am. Ord.
2012-04-0377O, passed 4-24-2012)



§ 94.36  TITLE.



   These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the City of Oak
Forest, hereinafter referred to as “this code.”



(2000 Code, § 8.40.020)  (Ord. 2914 § 2 (part), passed - -2005)



§ 94.37  FAILURE TO COMPLY.



   Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a
stop work order, except the work as that person is directed to perform or
remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less
than $50 or more than $250, or unless otherwise noted.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.040)  (Ord. 2914 § 2 (part), passed - -2005; Am. Ord.
2014-01-0482O, passed 1-14-2014)



§ 94.38  FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS.



   (A)   Approved automatic sprinkler systems are required in all new
buildings and structures except detached garages and sheds and except that,
in single-family residential structures, N.F.P.A. 13D requirements for
automatic sprinklers are amended to provide that bathrooms of less than 80
square feet and closets of less than 55 square feet are not required to have
sprinklers.



   (B)   Should an addition of 75% or more of the floor area of the
original single family residential building install automatic sprinklers in
any part of the existing building which shares a common wall or common
floor/ceiling with the addition, the primary resident will qualify for an
incentive of 50% of the total cost of the purchase and installation of the
automatic fire sprinkler system up to a maximum of $3,000. The resident will
need to provide a copy of their tax bill showing principle residency and
proof that three quotes were obtained to the City Administrator in order to
qualify for the incentive.



   (C)   Any single family home that installs automatic sprinkler heads
will qualify for an incentive of $100 per head with a maximum incentive of
$300. Proof of a paid bill and proof of an inspection by the city's Building
Department will need to be provided to qualify for the incentive.



   (D)   Retro-fit of any existing assembly occupancies of Class A-2 of
the lounge, nightclub, restaurants, taverns, bars and banquets halls that
have an occupancy of 200 or more and live entertainment are required to
install automatic sprinklers within two years of passage of this subchapter.
A change in ownership does not relieve the responsibility of this requirement.



   (E)   (1)   All manufactured homes, commonly known as mobile
homes, trailers, installed from the date of passage of these amendments shall
have automatic sprinklers installed.



      (2)   This would include any new or used units.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.050)  (Ord. 2914 § 3 (part), passed - -2005; Ord.
2006-07-0044O, passed 7-11-2006; Am. Ord. 2014-01-0482O, passed 1-14-2014;
Am. Ord. 2015-08-0554O, passed 9-22-2015)



§ 94.39  HAZARDOUS INCIDENT PROHIBITION.



   No person shall store, manufacture, produce, dispose of, treat,
transport or cause the use, storage, manufacture, production, treatment or
transportation of any hazardous substance or hazardous material in any manner
which results in a hazardous material incident.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.060)  (Ord. 2914 § 3 (part), passed - -2005)  Penalty,
see § 94.99



§ 94.40  SPILLER PAY REQUIREMENT.



   (A)   Any person causing or permitting a hazardous material incident
may be responsible for any and all of the following:



      (1)   Reimbursement in full for any and all costs incurred by
the city in connection with the operation, maintenance and staffing required
to respond to such hazardous material incident at the rates indicated in §
32.099(G);



      (2)   Reimbursement in full for any and all costs incurred by
the city for equipment and materials used, damaged, lost, spent, destroyed or
rendered irreparable in connection with a hazardous material incident; and/or



      (3)   Assumption of any and all liability and costs of any
cleanup or removal resulting from a hazardous material incident, including
but not limited to any independent clean-up contractor necessitated by the
hazardous material incident.



   (B)   The Fire Department/City Administrator shall prepare and
forward to the person or persons causing or permitting a hazardous material
incident, a bill for the total costs and expenses incurred for which such
person or persons are responsible pursuant to this section; provided,
however, any cost in connection with any independent clean-up contractor
shall be billed directly by the contractor. Payment of the total bill shall
be made within 30 days of receipt. Any bill or portion thereof remaining
unpaid after 30 days of receipt shall accrue interest on the unpaid balance
at the rate of one and one-half percent per month, or any fraction of a month.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.070)  (Ord. 2914 § 3 (part), passed - -2005; Am. Ord.
2018-04-06890, passed 4-24-2018)



§ 94.41  PROHIBITIONS.



   It is unlawful for any person or other legal entity to fail, refuse or
otherwise conduct himself or herself or itself contrary to the provisions of
the No Parking Without Consent, Storage Restriction and Hazardous Waste
Prohibition section of this chapter.



   (A)   Within city limits: storage of cryogenic fluids are prohibited
in all residential areas.



   (B)   Flammable and combustible liquids are prohibited in all
residential areas.



   (C)   Liquified petroleum gases are prohibited in all residential
areas.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.080)  (Ord. 2914 § 3 (part), passed - -2005)  Penalty,
see § 94.99




FIREWORKS




§ 94.55  TITLE.



   The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as the “Oak
Forest Fireworks Ordinance.”



(2000 Code, § 8.36.010)  (Ord. 2461 § 1, passed - -2000)



§ 94.56  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FIRE DEPARTMENT.  The Chief of the Fire Department or higher designee.



   FIREWORKS.  Includes any explosive composition, or any substance or
combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a
visible or an audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by
combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include the
following:



      (1)   Firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles,
bombs or other devices of similar construction;



      (2)   Any fireworks containing any explosive compound; or



      (3)   Any tablets or other devices containing any explosive
substance or containing combustible substances producing visual effects.



   FIREWORKS.  Shall not include the following:



      (1)   Auto flares;



      (2)   Snake or glow worm pellets;



      (3)   Smoke devices;



      (4)   Trick noisemakers known as “party poppers,” “booby
traps,” “snappers,” “trick matches,” “cigarette loads” and
“auto burglar alarms;”



      (5)   Sparklers. The term SPARKLERS means a wire or stick
coated with pyrotechnic composition which may not exceed 100 grams per item,
that produces a shower of sparks upon ignition. The term SPARKLERS shall not
include other sparking devices including but not limited to items commonly
known as “fountains,” “spinners,” “wheels” or similar devices,
the sale and use of which is expressly prohibited;



      (6)   Toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, other devices in which
paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths grams or less of
explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand
cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; or



      (7)   Toy pistol caps or plastic caps which contain less than
twenty-five hundredths grams of explosive mixture.



   MUNICIPALITY.  The City of Oak Forest.



   POLICE.  Any Oak Forest police officer.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.020)  (Ord. 2461 § 2, passed - -2000)



§ 94.57  FIREWORKS PROHIBITED.



   No person shall possess, store, offer for sale, expose for sale,
manufacture, sell at retail, use or explode any fireworks except as provided
in this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.030)  (Ord. 2461 § 3, passed - -2000)  Penalty, see §
94.99



§ 94.58  FIREWORKS DISPLAY PERMIT; APPLICATION.



   (A)   The applicant for a fireworks display permit shall submit an
application to the Fire Department at least 15 days in advance of the date of
the proposed fireworks display.



   (B)   Only persons or entities which operate fairs, amusement parks,
outdoor recreational facilities, governmental entities or persons or entities
authorized to use governmental property for a fireworks display may apply for
a fireworks display permit.



   (C)   The application shall state the date or dates of the fireworks
display, the location of the fireworks display and provide information about
the method of explosion, number, type and size of the fireworks to be
displayed as reasonably required by the Fire Department to determine the fire
safety precautions minimally necessary to protect the public and the safety
measures to be used to protect the public. The applicant shall state the name
of the fireworks display operator.



   (D)   Every permittee shall have and maintain adequate liability
insurance with minimum limits of $1,000,000 bodily injury and property
damage, combined single limit, naming the city, its officers, employees and
agents as additional insureds. That insurance shall indemnify and defend the
city, its officers, employees and agents against all claims, liability loss,
damages or expenses, whether caused by or contributed to by the negligence of
the city, its officers, employees or agents. The insurance shall provide that
the city receive written notice 30 days prior to any cancellation, nonrenewal
or material change in the policy. Proof of the insurance shall be submitted
to the Fire Department.



   (E)   The Fire Department shall approve and issue a fireworks
display permit to a person or entity if the applicant meets the conditions of
this chapter for a permit and the Fire Department determines that the
location and character of the proposed display is not in violation of any
federal, state or county law or ordinance or rule or regulation and is not a
hazard to property and will not endanger any person and the operator of the
fireworks display is competent to handle the display based upon the
operator’s experience and reputation for safety.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.040)  (Ord. 2461 § 4, passed - -2000)



§ 94.59  SMOKING BY OPERATOR AT FIREWORKS DISPLAY PROHIBITED.



   No person in charge of or working in connection with any public display
of fireworks shall smoke at any time during which the public display is going
on or in the vicinity of materials to be used for the display.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.050)  (Ord. 2461 § 5, passed - -2000)  Penalty, see §
94.99



§ 94.60  DISPOSAL OF UNFIRED FIREWORKS.



   Unfired fireworks and trash remaining after a public display of
fireworks for which a permit is issued shall be immediately disposed of in an
approved safe manner.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.060)  (Ord. 2461 § 6, passed - -2000)



§ 94.61  PARENTAL LIABILITY.



   A parent, foster or family-operated group home, parent or legal
guardian of a minor who consents to the use of fireworks by the minor who is
under the age of 18 years of age is liable for damages caused by the
minor’s use of the fireworks, and in addition shall be subject to the
penalty provided below.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.070)  (Ord. 2461 § 7, passed - -2000)



§ 94.62  ADVERTISING RESTRICTIONS.



   (A)   No person shall advertise fireworks within the corporate
limits of the city on any sign or billboard located within the city, or by
handbills or circulars distributed within the city.



   (B)   This section does not prohibit sending solicitations or
advertisements solely to persons possessing a public display permit under §
94.58 above.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.090)  (Ord. 2461 § 9, passed - -2000)  Penalty, see §
94.99



§ 94.63  SEIZURE OF FIREWORKS.



   The police shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed at the
expense of the owner all stocks of fireworks offered or exposed for sale,
manufactured, stored, possessed or held in violation of this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.100)  (Ord. 2461 § 10, passed - -2000)



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   (1)   The imposition of one penalty for any violation of
§§ 94.01 through 94.20 shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue. All offenders are required to correct or remedy the violations or
defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified, a separate
offense shall be deemed committed each ten days that prohibited conditions
are maintained.



      (2)   The application of the penalty set forth in § 94.01
shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions.



(2000 Code, § 8.16.210)



   (C)   Persons who shall violate a provision of §§ 94.35 through
94.41 or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who
shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved
construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit
or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a
violation of fire codes, punishable by a fine of not more than $500. Each day
after that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be
deemed a separate offense.



(2000 Code, § 8.40.030)  (Ord. 2914 § 2 (part), passed - -2005)



   (D)   Any person who violates any provision of §§ 94.55 through
94.63 shall be subject to a fine of not more than $750. Each day that a
violation of §§ 94.55 through 94.63  continues shall be considered a
separate and distinct offense.



(2000 Code, § 8.36.080)  (Ord. 2461 § 8, passed - -2000)
