GENERAL PROVISIONS; ADMINISTRATION



§ 95.01  SHORT TITLE.



   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Oak Forest Animal
Control Code of 2013.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.010)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ANIMAL.  Any living vertebrate, domestic or wild, not including man.



   ANIMAL CONTROL COMMISSION ("COMMISSION"). An available non-profit or
volunteer corporation, association or group, recognized by the Mayor and
known and operating within the city, able and willing to work in partnership
with Oak Forest Animal Control to advocate for and provide rescue and
re-homing of unclaimed and abandoned local animals.



   ANIMAL RESCUER.  Any person that volunteers for the care and welfare
of abused or neglected animals.



   ANIMAL SHELTER.  Any premises, within or without the city, designated
by Council for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals under
authority of this chapter.



   AT LARGE.  Any domestic animal when it is off the property of its
owner or not restrained by a competent person by a leash or chain when not on
the property of its owner or keeper.



   CAT.  Includes all animals of the feline family (Felis Catus).



   COMPETENT PERSON.  A person who is physically and mentally capable of
managing and controlling a domestic pet which is his or her responsibility
while off the premises of the owner or keeper thereof.



   DANGEROUS ANIMAL.  Any individual animal anywhere other than upon the
property of the owner or custodian and unmuzzled, unleashed or unattended by
its owner or custodian that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person
would believe poses a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious
physical injury or death to a person or a companion animal or a dog that,
without justification, bites a person and does not cause serious physical
injury.



   DOG.  Includes all animals, regardless of sex, of the canine species
(Canis Familiaris).



   DOMESTIC ANIMAL.  Any animal, except a farm or dangerous animal, which
has been domesticated so as to live and/or breed in a tame condition as a
household pet or guardian.  For the purpose of this chapter, ferrets,
pot-bellied pigs and rabbits are determined to be DOMESTIC ANIMALS.



   FEED.  The offering, giving or attempting to give food or non-food
items to wild animals.



   INOCULATION.  The injection, subcutaneously or otherwise, as approved
by the Department of Agriculture, of canine antirabic vaccine approved by the
Department.



   KENNEL.  Any person engaged in the business of breeding, buying,
selling or boarding cats or dogs.



   OWNER.  A person having a right of property of an animal, or who keeps
or harbors an animal, or who has a dog or other animal in his or her care, or
who acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or
about any premises occupied by him or her.



   RESTRAINT.  An animal that is controlled within a closed vehicle being
driven or parked on the streets, or that is within the property limits of the
owner or keeper or contained by a fence, a kennel or a leash or chain of
sufficient strength to control the dog or other animal.



   VETERINARY HOSPITAL.  Any establishment maintained and operated by a
licensed veterinarian for the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and
injuries of animals.



   WILD ANIMAL.  Any animal living in a natural, undomesticated state or
that is generally naturally occurring as undomesticated in the city such as
raccoons, skunks, coyotes, squirrels, etc.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.020) (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am. Ord.
2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2016-08-0615O, passed
8-9-2016; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.03  ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER AND ASSISTANT; POSITIONS ESTABLISHED;
COMMISSION CREATED.



   (A)   There is established the position of Animal Control Officer,
who shall be under the direction of the Director of Public Works.



   (B)   There is established the position of assistant to the Animal
Control Officer, who shall be under the direction of the Animal Control
Officer.



      (1)   The position of assistant to the Animal Control Officer
shall be an unpaid, volunteer position filled as necessary and in such
numbers as needed, as determined by the Animal Control Officer. The assistant
shall be appointed by the Director of Public Works.



      (2)   The assistant to the Animal Control Officer shall
primarily be responsible for assisting in the care of animals in the custody
of the city and for such other associated duties as the Animal Control
Officer shall direct.



      (3)   The assistant shall sign a waiver and release of
liability, acknowledging that the city has no responsibility for any injury,
disease or sickness of any kind that may occur due to the assistant’s
responsibilities.



   (C)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to identify and appoint an
appropriate Animal Control Commission capable of the rescue and care of lost
or abandoned animals and provide such designation to the city's Animal
Control Officer. The function and role of any such designated Commission is
to partner



and collaborate with the Animal Control Officer in the rescue and re-homing
of unclaimed and abandoned local animals, consistent with such
responsibilities as may be further set forth in this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.030)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2016-08-0615O,
passed 8-9-2016; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.04  DUTIES OF ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER.



   (A)   Under the direction of the Director of Public Works, the
Animal Control Officer shall have the full power of enforcement of this
chapter or any part thereof.



   (B)   The Animal Control Officer shall have full authority to issue
a citation or summons, sign formal complaints against violators and appear in
court as an agent on behalf of the city for the purpose of enforcement of
this chapter. The Public Works Department shall notify the Animal Control
Officer of all complaints involving domestic animals running at large.



   (C)   Whenever any domestic animal running at large is apprehended
it shall be taken to the kennel as is, from time to time, designated by the
city and a record shall be made of its description and its license tags, if
any. If it is licensed, a reasonable attempt will be made by the Animal
Control Officer to locate the owner thereof and inform him or her of the
animal’s apprehension.



   (D)   The Animal Control Officer shall remit to the city all moneys
collected by it for dog licenses, impounding fees and boarding fees, and
shall also submit a bill for the boarding of all unclaimed animals which are
brought to the kennel pursuant to this chapter.



   (E)   Any animal so impounded shall not be held more than 96 hours.
The care of any such domestic animal shall continue to be provided by the
city during the entire 96-hour period. At the expiration of such period, the
Animal Control Officer will consult and collaborate with the Animal Control
Commission regarding the assumption of the care, custody and control of the
animal. The Animal Control Officer will cooperate with the designated
Commission at the end of any such 96-hour impoundment period and allow the
Commission to assess and evaluate the animal. The Commission has no
obligation to accept the transfer of the animal and shall notify the Animal
Control Officer in writing if they will not accept the animal. The Animal
Control Officer is then authorized to move forward and make appropriate
decisions under the provisions of this chapter. If the Commission determines
to accept the animal, all responsibilities for the care, custody and control
of the animal will then be transferred to and be assumed by the Commission
with no further obligation, involvement, or responsibility on the part of the
city or the Animal Control Officer. All decision making thereafter regarding
the animal rests with the Commission, including placement and disposition of
the future care or custody of the animal.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.040)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2016-08-0615O,
passed 8-9-2016; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.05  ANIMAL CONTROL FACILITY.



   The city shall provide or contract to provide a suitable place for the
impounding of domestic animals.  The Commission designated to work with the
city and Animal Control Officer shall be allowed the access to and use of
this facility for the care of animals under the custody and control of the
Commission, provided there is available space.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.050)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2016-08-0615O,
passed 8-9-2016; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.06  MONEYS KEPT BY CITY TREASURER.



   All moneys received and paid out pursuant to this chapter shall be kept
in a separate account by the City Treasurer under the budget of the Public
Works Department.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.060)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.07  LICENSE REQUIRED; CERTIFICATE OF INOCULATION.



   (A)   No person shall own or keep a dog or domestic cat in the city
without first obtaining a license therefor.



   (B)   The license shall be obtained from the City Clerk by reporting
to the City Clerk’s office annually, within 30 days after July 1 each year,
the person’s name and address and the name, breed, color and sex of each
and every dog and domestic cat owned or kept by such person.



   (C)   The person shall pay to the City Clerk or his or her duly
authorized representative $5 as an annual license fee for each such dog and
domestic cat, and each such license shall expire on June 30 next following
its issuance.



   (D)   No such license shall be issued unless the owner presents a
certificate of inoculation for rabies from the County Health Department.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.070)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018) Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.08  DISPLAY OF TAGS.



   Every owner or keeper of a dog shall cause the dog to wear a collar or
harness and shall affix thereto a city license tag and a rabies control
inoculation tag.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.080)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-2-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.09  REMOVAL OF TAGS.



   No person, without the consent of the owner or keeper, shall remove a
license tag for which a license has been obtained.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.090)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018) Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.10  INOCULATION OF DOMESTIC ANIMALS.



   The requirements for inoculation of domestic animals is contained
within the Cook County Code of Ordinances Chapter 10 and adopted by this
chapter.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.100)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.11  EXHIBITION OF CERTIFICATES OF INOCULATION UPON REQUEST.



   Upon the request of the Public Works Department Animal Control Officer,
at any reasonable time, the owner or keeper of any unmuzzled dog or cat shall
exhibit his or her certificate, issued under § 95.10 above, showing the
inoculation against rabies of any dog or cat owned or controlled by him or
her.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.140)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



PROHIBITIONS; RULES FOR KEEPING



§ 95.25  RELEASE OF DOMESTIC ANIMALS.



   No person, other than a duly authorized employee or agent of the city,
shall untie any domestic animal that is in an enclosure or on the premises of
its owner or keeper or take or release any such domestic animal from the
enclosure or premises.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.150)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.26  ANIMALS AT LARGE; IMPOUNDING.



   (A)   No competent person shall cause, allow, permit or suffer a
domestic animal to be at large in the city. Any domestic animal shall be
deemed to be at large when it is off the property of its owner or keeper or
not restrained by a responsible person by a leash or chain when not on the
property of its owner or keeper.



   (B)   Employees and officers of the city, who are designated for the
purpose by the Director of Public Works, shall notify the Animal Control
Officer of the city as to any domestic animal found running at large or
unlicensed in the city contrary to any of the provisions of this chapter or
any other ordinance of the city.



   (C)   When domestic animals are found running at large or
unlicensed, the dogs or other animals may be impounded at the discretion of
the employees, but the employees may cite the owner of the domestic animals
to answer a charge of violating a provision of this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.160)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.27  NOTICE OF IMPOUNDING; ISSUANCE OF CITATION.



   In case of impounding, and where the owner or keeper of a domestic
animal is disclosed by any tax or license tag worn by it, or is otherwise
known to the officers impounding the same, the Public Works Department shall
at once give notice by mail or other means to the owner or keeper, informing
him or her of the impounding of his or her domestic animal, and may cite the
owner or keeper to answer a charge of violating a provision of this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.170)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.28  REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS.



   (A)   Any domestic animal impounded under this chapter, except such
as may have bitten any person as specified in § 95.30 below, shall, unless
sooner redeemed, be held for 72 hours in order to afford an opportunity to
the owner or keeper thereof to redeem the same. However, in cases where there
have been three or more tickets issued to the animal’s owner or keeper in
the preceding 12-month period for animals at large, the Animal Control
Officer or the Director of Public Works’ designee shall have the authority
to immediately transport the animal to an approved animal facility other than
the City of Oak Forest facility.



   (B)   Any such owner or keeper shall be required to pay all fees
associated with the impounding and release of the animal to the impounding
facility.



      (1)   If the owner of the domestic animal reclaims the same,
he or she shall pay the kennel an impounding fee of $20 and a boarding fee of
$20 per day for every day the dog or other animal is so impounded.



      (2)   Additionally, if the dog or cat is not licensed, the
owner shall acquire a license before the dog or cat is released to him or her.



   (C)   No dog or cat shall be released without having been inoculated
for the current calendar year, or in accordance with the requirement of the
Department of Agriculture. Upon payment of the required charges, the dog
shall thereupon be released to the owner or keeper.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.180)  (Ord. 2429, § 1 (part), passed - -1999; Ord.
2568, § 1, passed - -2001; Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.29  DESTRUCTION OF UNREDEEMED ANIMALS.



   Any impounded domestic animal which is not redeemed within 96 hours,
and is not transferred to a designated Animal Control Commission, may be
humanely destroyed or otherwise disposed of by the Animal Control Officer.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.190)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2016-08-0615O,
passed 8-9-2016; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.30  IMPOUNDING OF DOGS OR ANIMALS WHICH HAVE BITTEN PEOPLE.



   (A)   Whenever any animal bites any person, the owner of the animal
or anyone having knowledge of the bite shall immediately notify the Police
Department or Animal Control Officer.



   (B)   Any animal which has bitten or otherwise injured any person so
as to cause an abrasion of the skin shall be immediately taken, impounded and
kept separated from animals for ten days. If the animal has not been
currently inoculated, the animal shall be taken to a licensed veterinarian
for proper examinations and observations.



   (C)   If, during the examinations and observations in division (B)
above, the animal develops symptoms of illness; a veterinarian shall be
called to diagnose its condition. If the symptoms disclosed are such as to
indicate the presence of rabies, such animal shall be destroyed in such a
manner as to preserve intact the head, which shall thereupon be detached and
immediately sent to the diagnostic laboratory of the Department of
Agriculture.



   (D)   If a tranquilizer gun or taser is used to apprehend a stray or
vicious animal, which cannot be captured by normal means, the city and/or its
agents shall not be held responsible if the animal succumbs as a result of
the use of the tranquilizer gun or taser.



   (E)   If, at the expiration of ten days, no symptoms of rabies have
developed in the animal so impounded, the same may be redeemed by the owner
upon payment of the redemption fees and charges specified in § 95.28 above.
After having been notified that his or her dog has bitten or otherwise
injured any person, the owner or keeper thereof shall not, under any
circumstances, permit the animal to be at large unless securely muzzled.



   (F)   Any expense incurred in the handling of any animal under this
section shall be borne by the owner or keeper. No owner or keeper shall sell
or give away or otherwise dispose of any dog or other animal that is known to
have bitten a person, until it is released as required by law.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.200)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.31  CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED.



   No person shall keep any mule, ass, bovine, goat, sheep, poultry, fowl,
or any other non-domestic animal in the city. Horses and ponies are permitted
if the property is zoned Residential Estate.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.210)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09- 0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.32  NUMBER OF DOMESTIC ANIMALS TO BE KEPT.



   No person shall keep or maintain more than a total of three adult
domestic animals in, on or around a single-family dwelling, apartment, home
or domicile within the city. However, this shall not apply to licensed
kennels, pet shops, animal rescuers or a licensed veterinary hospital or
clinic.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.220)  (Ord. 2599 § 1, passed --2002; Am. Ord.
2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28- 2010; Am. Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed
3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.33  ANIMAL RESCUER.



   (A)   The city will allow up to two additional dogs to be housed
with an animal rescuer.



   (B)   To qualify as an animal rescuer, a person must submit an
application to the City Clerk.



   (C)   This application must include the following:



      (1)   Name and address of the applicant;



      (2)   The applicant and applicant’s address must be
registered with a national agency as an animal rescue facility;



      (3)   Proof that all dogs housed at the address are current
with all shots and vaccinations;



      (4)   Proof that all dogs residing at the address are
registered with the city as well as display current state and county tags; and



      (5)   A written consent to allow the increase in dogs from all
neighbors. For purposes of this section, NEIGHBOR means all properties that
immediately abut the property.



   (D)   Upon receipt of the application, the city shall conduct a
review of it records and make any investigations to determine whether there
have been any past violations of the Animal Control Code and that the
applicant’s location is suitable for housing any additional pets.



   (E)   Violations of the Animal Control Code shall be a sufficient
basis to deny any application.



   (F)   If municipal approval is granted, the applicant shall consent
to and allow unscheduled Animal Control Officer inspections of the location.



   (G)   The failure of any applicant to remain current with all
licenses, shots, vaccinations and registry, as well as to fully comply with
city ordinance shall result in a revocation of the animal rescuer designation.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.220)  (Ord. 2599 § 2, passed - -2002; Am. Ord.
2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed
3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.34  FERAL CAT COLONY.



   (A)   The city may enter into agreements with organizations
designated by the Cook County Animal Control office as participating in a
feral cat colony program in efforts to reduce the feral cat population.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for a person to provide food, water or
shelter to a colony of free-roaming cats, unless:



      (1)   The colony is a managed colony, registered with approved
sponsor; and



      (2)   Feral cat colony caretakers shall be entitled to
maintain and care for feral cats by providing food, water, shelter and other
forms of sustenance, provided that the feral cat colonies are registered with
a Cook County approved sponsor, and that the feral cat colony caretaker takes
all appropriate and available steps to meet the terms and conditions of this
section.



   (C)   Feral cat colonies are exempt from § 95.32.



   (D)   All persons maintaining a feral cat colony shall follow all
rules and regulations as established by the Cook County Code of Ordinances,
Chapter 10, Article IV Managed Care of Feral Cats.



(Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part),
passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.35  BREEDING.



   No person shall keep or maintain any animal for breeding purposes
within the city without the consent, in writing, of all property owners and
persons living within 500 feet each way from the place where it is proposed
to breed the animals.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.230)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.36  HOUSING AND SANITATION; REMOVAL OF EXCREMENT.



   (A)   Every owner shall provide domestic animals with adequate space
and housing and shall keep the same in a clean and sanitary condition and
free from filth, offal or other refuse.



   (B)   No competent person shall appear with an animal upon public
ways, within public places or upon the property of another, absent that
person’s consent, without some means for the removal of excrement, nor
shall any person fail to remove any excrement deposited by such animal. This
section shall not apply to a blind person while walking his or her guide dog.



   (C)   No person shall allow his or her animal to run at large and
deposit excrement upon public ways, within public places or upon the property
of another.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.240)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.37  PROXIMITY OF ANIMAL HOUSES TO RESIDENCES, CHURCHES OR SCHOOLS;
PROHIBITED STRUCTURES.



   (A)   No separate structure or enclosure used for the housing of
domestic animals shall be erected or maintained closer than 25 feet from any
residential unit or closer than 100 feet from any church or school. Such a
structure or enclosure shall otherwise comply with applicable building,
zoning, health and sanitation ordinances of the city and the statutes of the
state.



   (B)   No person shall build or erect, or cause to be built or
erected, any stable, barn, shed or other structure to be used for the
keeping, confining or housing of any animal that is not permitted in the
city, as set forth in § 95.31 above.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.250)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.38  INSPECTIONS.



   Separate space and housing used for more than three dogs or animals
shall be subject to inspection at reasonable times and hours by the Health
Commissioner or the Animal Control Officer.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.260)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.39  DISEASED ANIMALS.



   (A)   No person shall permit, suffer or allow a domestic animal
afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease to run at large or to be
exposed in any public place whereby the health of human or beast may be
affected.



   (B)   No person shall ship or remove a diseased animal from the
premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of competent
authority as designated by the Director of Public Works.



   (C)   It is the duty of the competent authority as designated by the
Director of Public Works to secure the disposition of any diseased animal and
the treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication and spread
of the contagion or infection, except in cases where the State Veterinarian
is authorized to act.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.270)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.40  DEAD ANIMALS.



   No person, being the owner of a dead animal, shall allow the animal to
remain for more than 12 hours within the city limits without being buried.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.280)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.41  DESTRUCTION OF ANIMALS; RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS.



   (A)   It is not the obligation of the city, upon an owner’s
request, to pick up a dog or other animal for the purpose of destroying it.



   (B)   That obligation rests solely with the owner.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.290)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.42  PET SHOPS AND KENNELS.



   In addition to the provisions for housing and sanitation contained in
this chapter, pet shops and kennels shall comply with other ordinances and
state statutes now in full force and effect and any ordinance or statute
amendatory or supplementary thereto pertaining to the licensing and
maintenance of pet shops and kennels.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.300)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.43  VETERINARY HOSPITALS.



   In addition to the provisions for housing and sanitation contained in
this chapter, veterinary hospitals shall comply with other ordinances and
state statutes now in full force and effect and any ordinance or statute
amendatory or supplementary thereto pertaining to the licensing and
maintenance of veterinary hospitals.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.310)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.44  CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.



   (A)   No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the city in any
way.



   (B)   Any person who inhumanely beats, tortures, starves, poisons,
overloads or abandons any animal shall be deemed guilty of a violation of
this section.



   (C)   No owner or person shall confine any animal in a motor vehicle
in a manner that places the animal in a life or health threatening situation
by exposure to a prolonged period of extreme heat or cold. In order to
protect the life and safety of an animal, an animal control officer, law
enforcement officer, or fire personnel who has reason to believe that this
section is violated shall have the authority to enter such motor vehicle by
any reasonable means under the circumstances, after making reasonable effort
to locate the owner or person.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.320)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018) Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.45  ANIMAL FIGHTS.



   No person shall instigate, cause or procure any dog fight, prize fight,
cock fight or any other public or private fighting between animals.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.330)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.46  HUNTING.



   (A)   No person shall kill, take or wound, or attempt to kill, take
or wound, with any shotgun, rifle, pistol, revolver, air gun or other
firearm, or a bow and arrow, any wild bird, wild game or wild animal in the
city.



   (B)   No person shall hunt, pursue, harass or disturb in any manner
any wild bird, wild game or wild animal in the city with a loaded shotgun,
rifle, pistol, revolver, air gun or other firearm, or a bow and arrow, with
the intent to use the same in the city.



   (C)   This section does not apply to any officer of the law while in
the performance of his or her duty, or to persons lawfully summoned by an
officer to assist him or her while those persons are so engaged in assisting
the officer.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.340)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.47  PEACE DISTURBANCE.



   No person shall keep any dog, whelp, bitch or other animal shut in or
tied up in any yard, house or other place, which animal, by barking, howling
or other noise, disturbs the peace and quiet of any family, individual or
neighborhood.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.350)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.48  ANIMALS PROHIBITED ON STREETS.



   (A)   No person shall ride, lead or drive, or cause to be ridden,
led or driven, on any public thoroughfare, parkway or shoulder of a road in
the city, any horse, pony, cattle, pig, goat or sheep.



   (B)   Animals may be ridden, led or driven along bridle paths and
across animal crossings as so designated and approved by the Mayor and
Council.



   (C)   Animals may be ridden, led or driven along a designated parade
route if they are direct participants in a parade approved by the City
Clerk’s office and if a parade permit has been issued.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.360)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.49  DANGEROUS ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE.



   No person, being the owner thereof, shall knowingly suffer, permit or
allow any dangerous, unruly, fierce or mischievous animal to run at large to
the danger, annoyance or damage of any other person or property.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.370)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.50  DESTRUCTION OF DANGEROUS ANIMALS.



   Members of the Police Department and the Animal Control Officer are
authorized to destroy any dangerous animal of any kind when it is necessary
for the protection of any person or property.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.380)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.51  DISPOSITION OF DOGS OR OTHER ANIMALS DEEMED NUISANCES.



   Any dog or other animal which, in any manner, continually disturbs the
quiet of any person or neighborhood, or destroys or injures any animal,
plant, shrub or other property that is not on the premises of its owner or
keeper, is declared to be a nuisance, and the dog or other animal shall be
taken up and impounded and may be redeemed or disposed of in the manner
provided for in §§ 95.28 through 95.30 above.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.390)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.52  VICIOUS DOGS.



   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      VICIOUS DOG.  A dog falling within any of the following
categories:



         (a)   Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or
disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury to or otherwise threaten
the safety of human beings or domestic animals;



         (b)   Any dog which, because of its vicious propensity,
is capable of inflicting injury, serious physical harm or death to humans,
and which would constitute a danger to human life or property if it were not
kept in the manner required by this chapter;



         (c)   Any dog which, without provocation, attacks or
bites, or has attacked or bitten, a human being or domestic animal; or



         (d)   Any dog owned or harbored primarily, or in part,
for the purpose of dog fighting, or any dog trained for dog fighting.



   (B)   Declaring a dog “vicious.” If the Animal Control Officer
or a public works supervisor has reason to believe that a dog falls within
any of the categories that would render it vicious, they shall investigate
the circumstances to determine whether the dog falls within the definition of
“vicious dog” as provided in this section. In the event that, following
investigation, the Animal Control Officer or public works supervisor
determines that the dog is a vicious dog, as defined in this section, they
may declare that the dog is vicious in accordance with this section.



   (C)   Notice of vicious dog declaration.



      (1)   Within seven days of a determination by the Animal
Control Officer or public works supervisor that a dog is vicious, the officer
making the determination shall notify the dog’s owner, if known, in
writing, of the declaration.



      (2)   This notice shall identify the requirements and
conditions for maintaining a vicious dog as set forth in this section.



      (3)   If the owner is unknown or cannot be located, the dog
may be immediately impounded.



      (4)   If the owner’s address is known, but the owner cannot
be located, the notice shall be posted on the owner’s property or sent by
certified mail to the owner’s last known address.



   (D)   Hearing on vicious dog declaration. The known owner of a
vicious dog shall have the opportunity to have a hearing on the declaration
in accordance with the following procedures:



      (1)   The owner of a dog that has been declared vicious in
accordance with this section shall have the right to file a written request
for a hearing to contest the declaration. Such a request must be filed with
the Director of Public Works within seven days after the owner received
notice of the vicious dog declaration. In the event that the owner fails to
file a written request for a hearing within the requisite seven-day period,
or fails to appear at a scheduled hearing, the owner will be deemed to have
waived the right to a hearing on the declaration. In that situation, the dog
shall be deemed vicious and the owner shall be required to comply with all of
the requirements and conditions for maintaining a vicious dog as set forth in
this section;



      (2)   Within seven days of the receipt of a written request
for a hearing, or as soon thereafter as is practical, a hearing shall be
scheduled and conducted by the City Administrator or his or her designee. The
hearing will be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The
owner and the city may be represented by counsel, present oral and written
evidence, and cross-examine witnesses;



      (3)   The City Administrator or his or her designee shall
issue a written decision within seven business days after the conclusion of
the hearing. The owner shall be mailed a copy of the written decision. The
decision of the City Administrator or his or her designee shall be final; and



      (4)   In the event that the City Administrator or his or her
designee upholds the vicious dog declaration, the owner shall comply with all
of the requirements and conditions for maintaining a vicious dog as set forth
in this chapter.



   (E)   Requirements for keeping a vicious dog. In order to keep or
permit a vicious dog within the corporate limits of Oak Forest, the owner of
a vicious dog shall be required to act in accordance with the following.



      (1)   Confinement.



         (a)   All vicious dogs shall be securely confined
indoors or in an enclosed and locked pen or structure upon the premises of
the owner.



         (b)   The pen or structure must have minimum dimensions
of five feet by ten feet, and must have secure sides and a secure top
attached to the sides.



         (c)   If no bottom is secured to the sides, the sides
must be embedded into the ground no less than two feet.



      (2)   Leash/muzzle. The owner of a vicious dog shall not allow
the dog to go outside its kennel, pen or structure, unless the dog is
muzzled, restrained by a chain or leash not more than four feet long, and
under the physical control of a person.



      (3)   Signs.



         (a)   The owner of a vicious dog shall display a clearly
visible warning sign, in a prominent place on his or her premises, indicating
that there is a vicious dog on the premises.



         (b)   The sign must be legible from the public streets
or thoroughfares upon which the owner’s property adjoins.



         (c)   The owner shall also display a sign with a symbol
warning children of the presence of a vicious dog.



         (d)   Exact or similar signs shall be posted on the
dog’s kennel, pen or enclosed structure.



      (4)   Insurance.



         (a)   The owner of a vicious dog must maintain public
liability insurance providing a minimum amount of $500,000 of coverage,
insuring the owner for any damage or personal injury which may be caused by
his or her vicious dog.



         (b)   Upon a declaration that a dog is vicious, the
owner of a vicious dog must provide proof to the City Clerk that the owner
possesses the required insurance.



         (c)   Upon request of the city, the owner may be
required to present proof of insurance, upon occasion, demonstrating that the
owner is maintaining the insurance.



      (5)   Notice of change of status. The owner of a vicious dog
shall notify the city’s Animal Control Officer or the Public Works
Department immediately upon learning that the vicious dog is unconfined or on
the loose, or if the dog has attacked a human being or domestic animal.



      (6)   Notice of change of ownership.



         (a)   If the owner of a dog declared to be vicious
pursuant to this section sells, gives away or otherwise transfers custody or
ownership of the vicious dog, the owner shall, within three days of the sale
or transfer, provide the city’s Animal Control Officer or Public Works
Department with the name, address and telephone number of the vicious dog’s
new owner or custodian.



         (b)   The owner shall notify the new owner or custodian
of the dog’s designation as a vicious dog.



         (c)   If the new owner or custodian resides or keeps the
dog within the corporate limits of the City of Oak Forest, the owner shall
inform the new owner or custodian of the requirements and conditions for
keeping a vicious dog as established in this chapter.



   (F)   Order for impoundment and destruction. The Animal Control
Officer,  police watch commander, or public works supervisor may order the
impoundment and destruction of a dog upon occurrence of one of the following:



      (1)   The dog has attacked, bitten, injured or killed a human
being or domestic animal;



      (2)   The dog has been declared to be vicious pursuant to this
section and the owner has failed to comply with the requirements and
conditions for keeping a vicious dog in accordance with this section; or



      (3)   The dog poses a threat of serious harm to the public
health or safety.



   (G)   Notice of impoundment or destruction. Within seven days of an
impoundment, the officer ordering the impoundment or destruction of a dog
shall notify the dog’s owner, if known, in writing, of the impoundment or
destruction.



   (H)   Hearing on impoundment or destruction. The known owner of a
vicious dog shall have the opportunity to have a hearing on the impoundment
or recommended destruction in accordance with the following procedures.



      (1)   The owner of a dog that has been impounded pursuant to
the provisions of this section shall have the right to file a written request
for a hearing to contest the impoundment.



         (a)   Such a request must be filed with the Public Works
Director within seven days after the owner received notice of the impoundment.



         (b)   In the event that the owner fails to file a
written request for a hearing within the requisite seven-day period, or fails
to appear at a scheduled hearing, the owner will be deemed to have waived the
right to a hearing on the impoundment.



         (c)   In that situation, the Director of Public Works
may order the destruction of the dog or take any other steps he or she deems
necessary to protect the public health or safety from the potential danger
posed by the dog.



      (2)   Within seven days of the receipt of a written request
for a hearing, or as soon thereafter as is practical for the city
administration, a hearing shall be scheduled by the city. The hearing shall
be conducted by the City Administrator or his or her designee. The hearing
will be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The owner and
the city may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence,
and cross-examine witnesses.



      (3)   The City Administrator or his or her designee shall
issue a written decision within seven business days after the conclusion of
the hearing. The owner shall be mailed a copy of the written decision. The
decision of the City Administrator shall be final.



      (4)   After considering all of the relevant evidence presented
at a hearing in accordance with this division, the City Administrator or his
or her designee may order the destruction or continued impoundment of the
dog, or may release the dog to its owner conditional on the owner complying
with the requirements for keeping a vicious dog as established in this
section, and conditional on the owner complying with any other requirements
that the Director of Public Works deems necessary to protect the public
health or safety from the potential danger posed by the dog.



   (I)   Exemptions. This section shall not apply to the following:



      (1)   Dogs used by the Police Department or a law enforcement
agency;



      (2)   Dogs that have injured a person, or the property of a
person, who was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises
of the dog’s owner; and



      (3)   Dogs that have injured a person, or the property of a
person, who was teasing, taunting, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog.



   (J)   Dog fighting prohibited. No person shall possess, harbor or
maintain the care or custody of any dog for the purpose of dog fighting, nor
shall any person train, torment, badger, bait or otherwise use any dog for
the purpose of fighting or for the purpose of causing or encouraging the dog
to attack human beings or domestic animals.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.400)  (Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am.
Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O,
passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.53  CANINE UNIT EXEMPTION.



   Trained police dogs utilized by an official law enforcement agency and
assigned to a sworn peace officer as part of a canine team/unit shall be
exempt from all provisions of this chapter as well as any applicable
provision of any other chapter of this code.



(Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part),
passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.54  WILD ANIMALS.



   (A)   The city provides animal control services for wild animals on
public and private property if the animal is sick or injured or poses a
threat to human safety.



   (B)   Removal of wild animals that do not pose an immediate threat
must be done by a State of Illinois licensed private wildlife removal service.



   (C)   No person on public or private property shall attract or feed
wild and/or stray domestic animals, including but not limited to stray cats,
stray dogs, seagulls, geese, skunks, raccoons, squirrels or deer within the
city limits.  Nothing contained herein shall prohibit persons from feeding
birds on their private property using bird feeders or other receptacles. 
This section shall not apply to an Animal Control Officer in the performance
of his or her official duties or to state and/or federal wildlife officials
in the performance of their official duties.



(Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28-2010; Am. Ord. 2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part),
passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed 2-27-2018)



§ 95.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



(2000 Code, § 6.04.410)  (Ord. 2417 (part), passed - -1999; Ord. 2429 § 1
(part), passed - -1999; Am. Ord. 2010-09-0307O, passed 9-28- 2010; Am. Ord.
2013-03-0434O, § 2 (part), passed 3-12-2013; Am. Ord. 2018-02-0681O, passed
2-27-2018)

BUSINESS LICENSES GENERALLY




§ 110.001  APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER.



   This subchapter shall govern the licensing of the various trades,
businesses and professions in this Title XI, except to the extent that the
same is governed by other provisions in this title.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.010)



§ 110.002  LICENSE OR PERMIT REQUIRED.



   No person shall operate any business or establishment, or engage in any
business, activity or occupation, for which a license fee is provided in this
business regulation title, without having first obtained a license or permit
for the business, activity or occupation.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.020)  Penalty, see § 110.999



§ 110.003  APPLICATIONS.



   (A)   Applications for licenses and permits required by this
business regulation title shall be made in writing to the City Clerk, who is
the Business License Commissioner of the city, upon forms provided by him or
her.



   (B)   Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the
license or permit desired, the location to be used, if any, and the square
footage of the premises to be used by the licensee, and each application
shall contain such additional information as may be required by this business
regulation title or requested by city officials.



   (C)   No license or permit shall be issued until the applicant has
furnished all information requested by the City Clerk or other municipal
official and until all other city ordinances are complied with.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.030)



§ 110.004  FORMS.



   Forms for all licenses and permits issued under this business
regulation title and applications therefore shall be prepared and kept on
file by the City Clerk.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.040)



§ 110.005  SIGNATURES.



   Each license or permit issued under this business regulation title
shall bear the signatures of the Mayor and the City Clerk in the absence of
any provision to the contrary.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.050)



§ 110.006  INSPECTIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS.



   Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit, in those cases
where the ordinances of the municipality necessitate an inspection or
investigation, the City Clerk shall, before the issuance of the permit or
license, refer the application to the proper officer for the investigation or
inspection within 48 hours of the time of the receipt. The officer charged
with the duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a report
thereon, in writing, within ten days after receiving the application. The
Health Commissioner shall make inspections of all premises in regard to
compliance with sanitation regulations; the Fire Chief shall make inspections
in regard to compliance with fire regulations; and the Building Commissioner
shall make or cause to be made inspections in regard to compliance with
ordinances relating to the construction of buildings or other structures. All
investigations, except where otherwise provided, shall be made by the Chief
of Police or by some other officer designated by the Mayor.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.060)



§ 110.007  FEES.



   (A)   All fees and charges for licenses and permits shall be paid in
advance to the City Clerk at the time the application therefor is filed.
Business licenses shall be issued annually, and fees shall be based on a full
year rate, which shall cover the whole year or any portion of the license
period for which application is made.



   (B)   Except where otherwise provided in this business regulation
title, the annual license or permit fee for a business, activity, occupation
or profession shall be computed as follows.



      (1)   Base license fee $50; plus



      (2)   Annual occupancy inspection fee:

      (5)   Business registration fee: $50.



      (6)   As to any of the businesses housed in a commercial
building where state law has preempted local authority, and are subject to an
annual fire inspection by the Oak Forest Fire Department, the City of Oak
Forest shall require an annual business registration administrative fee of
$50. This charge will be used to reimburse the city for municipal costs
associated with the annual fire inspection and to confirm the business is in
full compliance of state laws.



   (C)   In computing square footage, the entire building floor area
and any adjacent storage or display area shall be included. The license or
permit fee based on square footage entitles the licensee to one building. An
additional license or permit shall be obtained for any other business or
place of business conducted at the same address, under the same roof or on
the same property of the licensee.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.070)  (Ord. 2006-12-0072O, passed 12-12-2006)



§ 110.008  ISSUANCE OF LICENSES AND PERMITS TO PERSONS INDEBTED TO CITY.



   No license or permit shall be issued to any person who owes money to
the city in the form of any unpaid assessment or who is in any other way
indebted to the city, until the person discharges his or her indebtedness
then due to the city.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.080)



§ 110.009  ASSIGNMENT AND TRANSFER OF LICENSES AND PERMITS.



   No license or permit granted under this business regulation title shall
be assigned or transferred, unless otherwise expressly authorized.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.090)  Penalty, see § 110.999



§ 110.010  REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF LICENSES AND PERMITS.



   Any license or permit issued under this business regulation title may
be revoked by the Mayor or the Business License Commissioner at any time for
any violation by the licensee or permittee of any ordinance relating to the
license or permit. The revocation shall be in addition to any fine imposed.
However, no such license or permit shall be revoked or suspended except after
a public hearing by the Mayor or the Business License Commissioner, with
reasonable notice to the licensee served by registered or certified mail,
return receipt requested, at least seven days prior to the hearing, at the
last known place of business of the licensee, and after an opportunity to
appear and defend. The notice shall specify the time and place of the hearing
and the nature of the charges. The finding of the Mayor or the Business
License Commissioner shall be predicated upon competent evidence. However, in
cases involving food establishment violations, or where there is imminent
danger to the safety or health of the public, no public hearing is necessary
in order to revoke or suspend any license or permit.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.100)



§ 110.011  POSTING OF LICENSES AND PERMITS.



   Every licensee conducting a business in the city shall keep the license
or permit therefor posted in a prominent place on the premises used for the
business.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.110)



§ 110.012  TERMINATION OF LICENSES AND PERMITS; NOTICE AND LATE FEES.



   (A)   All annual licenses and permits shall terminate on December
31, where no provision to the contrary is made.



   (B)   The City Clerk shall mail to all licensees of the city a
statement of the time of expiration of the license or permit held by the
licensee, if it is an annual one, three weeks prior to the date of the
expiration. However, failure to send out the notice, or the failure of the
licensee to receive it, shall not excuse the licensee from a failure to
obtain a new license or permit, or a renewal, nor shall it be a defense in an
action for operation without a license or permit.



   (C)   If a business license is not renewed before January 1, a $50
late fee shall be added to such license or permit.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.120)  (Am. Ord. 2015-10-0562O, passed 10-27-2015)



§ 110.013  CHANGE OF LOCATION OF LICENSED BUSINESS; NOTICE.



   The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any
permitted act, may be changed, provided that ten days’ notice thereof is
given to the City Clerk. The new location must be in compliance with these
codified ordinances and all other ordinances of the city.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.130)



§ 110.014  BUSINESSES AS NUISANCES.



   No business shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a
nuisance in fact.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.140)  Penalty, see § 110.999



§ 110.015  RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION.



   (A)   Whenever an inspection of a business or of a premises used for
or in connection with the operation of a business or occupation is provided
for, or is reasonably necessary to ensure compliance with any ordinance, the
licensee or the person in charge of the premises shall admit thereto, for the
purpose of making the inspection, any authorized officer or employee of the
municipality.



   (B)   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is necessary
to ensure conformity with any ordinance, the licensee shall give, to any
authorized officer or employee of the municipality requesting the same,
sufficient samples of the material or commodity for the analysis.



   (C)   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the
Mayor or the Business License Commissioner may revoke any license or permit
if the licensee refuses to permit any officer or employee to make an
inspection or to take an adequate sample of a desired commodity, or
interferes with the officer or employee while in the performance of his or
her duty. However, no license or permit shall be revoked for the cause unless
written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises,
in the name of the municipality, stating that the inspection or sample is
desired.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.150)



§ 110.016  IDENTIFICATION OF TRUCKS.



   Any truck used in the conduct of any business or occupation licensed
under this business regulation title shall bear thereon, in legible
characters, the name and address of the operator of the business.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.160)



§ 110.017  MAINTENANCE OF PREMISES; COMFORT FACILITIES.



   The public portion of the premises of all businesses and occupations
licensed under this business regulation title shall be kept in a clean,
orderly and sanitary condition. The Chief of Police, the Fire Chief and the
Health Commissioner are authorized to make inspections to determine that the
premises are maintained in accordance with this section. All licensees shall
provide toilet and lavatory facilities for employees.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.170)



§ 110.018  PERIODIC INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   Fire inspections. The premises of all businesses licensed
under this business license title shall be inspected periodically by the Fire
Chief to ensure that the premises are maintained so that fire exits and other
means of ingress and egress to the premises are not blocked so as to hinder
egress from the premises. The Chief shall also determine that fire
extinguishers and the general condition of the premises are maintained in
accordance with the Fire Prevention Code.



   (B)   Building inspections. The premises of all licensed businesses
shall be inspected periodically by the Building Commissioner to ensure that
the premises have not become unsafe for the public or employees of the
licensee.



(2000 Code, § 5.02.180)




WEIGHTS AND MEASURES




§ 110.030  SCALES REQUIRED.



   (A)   Every person selling or offering for sale any service
commodity, produce or article of merchandise sold by weight shall keep and
maintain, in a conspicuous place on his or her premises, scales suitable for
weighing the commodity, produce or article of merchandise, and shall,
whenever requested by a buyer and in the buyer’s presence, weigh the
commodity, produce or article of merchandise.



   (B)   Whenever meat, poultry or other articles of merchandise sold
by weight and prepared or wrapped in advance of being sold by a retailer are
being offered for sale, an accurate computing scale of adequate capacity
shall be placed or set not more than 30 feet from the prepackaged display
counter or service area. A prominent and conspicuous sign shall be placed on
or adjacent to the computing scale, which sign shall read “for customer
use”, in a type size not less than two inches in height. Where the
prepackaged merchandise is marked with weight expressed in the standard
avoirdupois pound and decimal fractions thereof, a conversion chart showing
the correlation between the decimal fractions and common fractions of the
avoirdupois pound, in a type size not less than 12 point, shall be
prominently and conspicuously displayed.



(2000 Code, § 5.66.010)  Penalty, see § 110.999



§ 110.031  FALSE WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.



   (A)   No person shall sell, offer for sale or keep for the purpose
of sale, any commodity in a quantity or enumeration of less weight or measure
than that represented upon the sale or offer for sale by the vendor or his or
her agent or employer. No person shall sell or offer for sale any commodity
in any receptacle having a smaller capacity than is represented at the time
of the offer or sale. No person shall sell or offer for sale any article of
dry or liquid measurement in other than the legal type of measure required
therefor.



   (B)   No person weighing or measuring any commodity for sale by dry,
liquid, lineal or superficial measurement, by any unit of enumeration used in
determining or measuring quantity or by weight, shall falsify the measure or
weight of the commodity by representing the measure or weight of the same to
be either more or less than the true measure or weight thereof.



   (C)   No person performing services upon any commodity, who
determines the charge for the services according to the measure or weight of
the commodity upon which the services are performed, shall falsify the
measure or weight of the same by representing the measure or weight to be
more than the true measure or weight thereof.



   (D)   No person shall deliver to a purchaser or prospective
purchaser any commodity in a quantity or enumeration of less weight or
measure than that offered for sale.



(2000 Code, § 5.66.020)  Penalty, see § 110.999




CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION




§ 110.045  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CONTRACTOR. A person engaging in the business of any of the building or
related trades set forth in this subchapter.



   DEVELOPER.  A person who has ownership or control over a parcel or
tract of land which is or is intended to be the site of two or more buildings
and who will, in accordance with city ordinances, improve or develop the land
with the installation of any one or more of the following: streets, curbs,
sanitary sewers or storm sewers. A DEVELOPER may also be a building
contractor, but he or she shall be required to have only the developer’s
registration.



   GENERAL CONTRACTOR.  A person engaging in the business of contracting
or hiring one or more trade contractors to perform the service of the trade
contractor.



(2000 Code, § 5.14.010)



§ 110.046  SUBCONTRACTORS.



   Any person doing business as a subcontractor shall be construed as
being engaged in the business of a building contractor for which a
registration is required by this chapter.



(2000 Code, § 5.14.020)



§ 110.047  REGISTRATION FEES.



   (A)   Annual registration fees for contractors, effective January 1,
1990, shall be as follows:

$100
